title: brexit news latest backstop dup theresa may belfast
story: Speaking in Belfast, the PM vowed to back a joint bid for the  World Cup by all the countries of the British Isles.And she pledged that after Brexit, the UK will have a closer relationship with Ireland than with any other European country.Mrs May also risked angering her MPs by suggesting she might not ditch the backstop after all.In a speech aimed squarely at winning goodwill from Dublin, the PM said: Our relationship with Ireland is deeper than our relationship with any of the other . It is uniquely rooted in ties of family, history and geography.The recent past has been a moment of reflection in the UK and Ireland as we have commemorated the centenary of a series of key events in our shared history.Today those ties of family and friendship between our countries are more important than they have ever been.And I believe there is a yearning in the hearts of all the peoples of these islands for a close and trusting relationship between all of us, and an absolute horror that we should take even a single step backwards in the progress we have collectively achieved.She proposed annual meetings between the British and Irish governments after Brexit to ensure the two countries work closely together.And she added: Both the UK and the Irish Governments have already made clear that we would support the tantalising possibility of a joint UK and Ireland World Cup bid for , should our respective football associations choose to pursue this.Mrs May admitted she must face up to the fact that MPs resoundingly rejected the Irish backstop plan - which could leave the UK trapped in the European customs union.But she hinted she may not ditch the backstop altogether, saying that any Brexit deal will need an insurance policy for the future.Earlier today DUP leader Arlene Foster vowed to back the PMs dealshe succeeds in rewriting the plan for the Irish border.The DUP are crucial to Mrs Mays strategy - because she believesthey come on board and back her deal, dozens of Tory Brexiteers will follow.Today Mrs Foster told the BBC: If the backstop is dealt with in the withdrawal agreement, then despite the fact that we may have misgivings around other parts of the agreement, we will support the Prime Minister.Because we do want Brexit to happen in an orderly fashion.The unionist boss said the current backstop would have to be replaced by a dferent way of keeping the Irish border open.She promised to lobby Mrs May on the issue when they hold talks in Belfast tomorrow.She said: We will be reiterating our opposition to the current backstop. And the fact that Parliament has now backed that position means that she has a clear mandate to go back to Brussels.The current backstop is toxic to those of us living in Northern Ireland, and indeed for unionists right across the United Kingdom, because it would cause the break-up of the United Kingdom into the medium and longer term.Mrs May got a boost from Angela Merkel yesterday as the German leader called on Brussels to be flexible with Britain.And a grand committee of Tory MPs from across the Brexit ide is meeting civil servants for a second day of talks on how to find alternative arrangements which could replace the backstop.

title: corbyn second brexit referendum frankenstein
story: In a huge blow for Remainers who hope that the Labour boss will eventually throw his weight behind another Brexit vote, the uncovered video shows him slamming the bloc.And he mocked the idea of a second referendum too, saying he had a feeling theyre going to keep on voting to get the answer they want after Ireland narrowly rejected adopting the Lisbon Treaty, a video unearthed by the Red Roar revealed.In a rally in  he branded the EU as subservient to Nato and said he did not want to live in a European empire of the st century.At the event organised by the Irish Anti-War movement he said he wished Britain would have a referendum too on whether to accept the new demands from the bloc.Backbencher Mr Corbyn blasted: Under the terms of the Lisbon Treaty, Europe will become subservient to the wishes of Nato and the aims of Nato.We are creating for ourselves here one massive Frankenstein, which will damage all of us in the long run.Mr Corbyns Remain supporters think he will cave and back a fresh vote to stay in the European Union.But this video shows the Labour boss true colours - and shows that hopes he will come out in favour of a second Brexit referendum to overturn the result are incredibly slim.Even Brexiteer Nigel Farage praised the speech, saying he was a real Eurosceptic.He went on: His role will be crucial over the next few weeks.Will the real Jeremy Corbyn please stand up And SNP MP Stewart McDonald tweeted earlier: He and Farage were singing from the same song sheet, albeit from dferent ends of the political spectrum.Mr Corbyn has a long history of Euroscepticism and famously was slammed for taking a back seat in the  EU referendum.Since then hes had to walk a tightrope over Brexit to try and keep all sides of his party happy.BRITAIN should continue allow free movement in some forms after we leave, Sir Keir Starmer has said.In a signicant softening of Labours position the Shadow Brexit Secretary called for Britain to allign with the EU after we leave.He said people would be willing to accept free movement of people with some restrictions - like advertising a job locally first, or bringing family members over.Sir Keir told the BBC: If somebody is coming to do a job and it needs to be done and it has been advertised locally beforehand with nobody able to do it, then most people would say I accept that.Most people say thatyou are coming to join your family that is something I can accept. Most people would saysomebody wants to come here and study and it is genuine then of course please come and study. In fact lets celebrate that.Theresa May has vowed that free movement will end after Brexit, and has insisted that Britain will finally be able to take back control of our borders once again after we leave.Voters said that immigration was one of the major factors in voting to leave the bloc.Labour has fiercely opposed Mrs Mays Brexit deal but stopped short of endorsing a second referendum.They say they will only back another votethey cant force through a general election to seize power.A spokesperson for Mr Corbyn said today: Jeremy’s criticisms of the Lisbon Treaty over a lack of democracy in the EU, its strengthening of neoliberal economic policies and potential military expansion are well known.That’s why he campaigned both to remain and reform in the  EU referendum, so it could live up to the promise of a social Europe.He is clear that a public vote must remain an option on the table to prevent the damage of a No Deal exit from the EU.

title: no deal brexit would be fault of stubborn eurocrats playing hardball top brexiteer storms
story: Chris Grayling launched a barnstorming attack on Brussels sayingwe left without a deal they would be entirely to blame, and not us.Just hours before it was revealed that Theresa May will dash to Brussels this week for talks with the EU over her deal, he said that Britain was doing all it could to try and reach agreement.But he warned in an interview with The Daily :  If they are not willing to compromise,theyre not willing to work with us to find common ground - it will be down to themthere is no deal.And he added: We want to work with the EU to reach a deal butthey are not prepared to do that - they will have to take responsibility that we are heading towards a no-deal exit.The EU have repeatedly insisted that they wont budge on the Irish border - saying the deal is done and dusted.He insisted Mrs May would be tough in the upcoming talks, but that there would be no chance of Article  being delayed at all.Ive been in every Cabinet meeting and theres been no conversation about delaying post-March , he said.We are not delaying Article .And Mr Grayling also slapped down scaremongering reports of food shortages after we leave the EU by saying: No, Im not stockpiling.Trade would continue to flow freely after we leave no matter what happens, we insisted.So its not a case that once we leave the EU that food supplies will suddenly dry up.His comments were echoed today by ex-Brexit boss Dominic Raab.In an interview with ConservativeHome this morning he said that: It will be important for people to see thatthe EU remain stubbornly intransigent, they are the ones courting the WTO exit.People understand that we need to leave on th March. Whether they voted Leave or Remain, the one thing you hear is get this thing done and dusted.Leaving without a deal wouldnt be the end of the world, but it wouldnt be a walk in the park, he said, which is also the view of Roberto Azevedo, the Director of the World Trade Organisation.Mr Raab even hinted that Britain could be SAFER after Brexit - because well be able to refuse entry to anyone that border officials are worried about.Britain is due to leave the EU on March  no matter what happens, but the PM has promised to go back and ask for changes to the hated Northern Irish backstop.Mrs May is still clinging to her deal, but accepts that MPs dont want it in its current form.She will come up with the plan to take to Brussels later this week which involves major changes to the Northern Ireland border.

title: brexit work begins to turn m20 into huge lorry park if we leave with no deal
story: Transport Minister Jesse Norman has told MPs that Highways England will “start installing contraflow infrastructure” such as steel barriers and new signs shortly.Under the Government plans – dubbed “Operation Brock” - a  –mile stretch of the east-bound carriageway could be used to hold , trucks in the case of chaos at Dover.So-called “non-port” traffic will then travel both ways on the west-bound route.The revelations come a day after HM Customs  Exciserevealed it would wave through EU goods that arrive at  ports across the UK in a No Deal to avoid jams.In a ministerial statement today, Mr Norman said the European Commission had indicated hauliers would keep “basic rights” to take shipments to the EUthe UK leaves without a deal.But he added there was still no final agreement with Brussels.And he said the Government may have to strike inidual deals with member states to keep trucks on the road.Haulage bosses have slammed Ministers for the delays in producing a clear plan of what could happen in a No Deal.They claim the French are still in the dark about what the Department for Transport is considering.Today, Mr Norman said a mere  annual permits may be available for hauliers to trade in the EUBrussels forces Britain to rely on permits.But he added: “It is important to be clear that the Government does not expect to rely on ECMT permits for hauliers to travel to EU member states, and is also making preparations to agree and implement bilateral arrangements for access,necessary.”

title: danny dyer right royal family flaw
story: A documentary that was as funny as it was surprising, and all the more so because the BBC did the right thing and played it absolutely straight.Genuine blue plaque television, in fact, that should never have been revisited or reformatted, not least because it would remind the Beeb that Danny’s wonderful everyman story had killed the whole WDYTYA franchise.So I’d been expecting this sucker punch, ever since its final credits rolled in .Danny Dyer’s Right Royal Family, on BBC. “A potty old adventure,” as his nibs described it, tracing Danny’s family line even further back, to Scandinavia’s King Rollo, his -times great grandfather, who I’d always assumed was a s children’s cartoon character, rather than a ninth-century Viking warrior.There were two episodes of it this time as well, which I know some of you thought were as funny as the original. Personally, I didn’t.What I hope we’re all agreed on, though, is the fact that Danny’s too busy playing Danny Dyer, the professional geezer, to be a good listener or natural TV historian.It’s an act that worked, of course, when he was wondering, “Eleanor of Aquitaine, was she a looker ” but didn’t serve him so well when presented with a longbow.“Long, innit ”The Beeb clocked this before production started, obviously, so had paired him up with dozens of head-patting historians and actors who got him to dress up as every kind of medieval t**t you can imagine. Like Mr Benn on crack, it was.Armour, codpieces, nappies, tights, doublet and hose, and a gigantic white smock, bleached with human urine, which had one grovelling “courtier” wondering: “Has all the p*** been washed out, my Lord King ”A good question.We didn’t actually get the answer, though, until part two, on Wednesday, when, after a brief detour round his ancestors, Louis IX of France, William the Conqueror and Henry II, viewers got to the nub of things, with Professor Chris Given-Wilson explaining the agonising death of Edward II: “By thrusting a hollow instrument, like the end of a trumpet, up his fundament.”“’Old on a minute,” said a rattled Danny. “He’s been stabbed  With a trumpet ”“Into his fundament.” Long pause.“Don’t tell me it’s up his a**e ”Right up it, Danny, with a red-hot poker. News which didn’t just do his “nut in”, it seemed to derail the entire documentary.They ran out of direct royal ancestors shortly afterwards as well, and the BBC adopted its stupid default setting in such circumstances. It turned Danny’s Right Royal Family into a dance and cookery show, complete with demonstrations of both, from medieval experts.It was about this time I also sussed out what was going on in the background, with all those winsome historians. An audition.The BBC was using it to find its new face of history, though why any of the blokes turned up is a mystery. Auntie’s already made it clear: “The days of white, middle-aged men explaining stuff are over.”Danny, on the other hand, can be tolerated, because he’s their new performing Cockney. A novelty act who can be dressed up and patronised so much he ended this one doing some weird medieval can-can, with his family, in front of his lost ancestral pile.A trumpet wasn’t quite shoved up his fundament as they danced, but the p*** had very much been washed out of him, my Lord King.GREAT TV lies and delusions of the month. “I think it’s going to be a really great show.” Cheryl Tweedy, The Greatest Dancer.“We do TV shows and we’re national treasures.” Jedward, Celebrity Coach Trip.“People will remember my name and I love that.” Some t**t off Ship- wrecked.IF you’re to take anything from the news experts have claimed Monday, January  was the most depressing day of the year, it’s probably the fact the experts clearly never sat through what happened eight days later, on Tuesday, January .Britain’s Top  Dogs Live: . All two-and-a-half yapping hours of it, on ITV, with a bad hangover, in the company of presenters Ben Fogle and Sara Cox.A test beyond personal endurance not because of the alcohol or dogs, who are a largely blameless lot, but the presence of their barmy owners, who attribute all sorts of superpowers to their dumb little mutts and blur the human animal relationship way beyond the point of reason and sometimes even good taste.Hits Radio DJ Gemma Atkinson, for instance, claimed: “I wouldn’t be where I am today without Norman”, her pet sproodle.Which is a hell of a guilt trip to pin on any dog.While Spandau Ballet’s Martin Kemp was seen, sitting alongside Popsie the poodle and his Wham! backing-singer we Shirlie, exclaiming: “I’ll say this for her,she does do a poo she goes into the spare bathroom.”The least you’d expect, frankly, after  years of marriage.The case study that really finished me off, though, was a dog dancing instructor called Joan Clark and her powder puff hounds, whose act, as described by Sara Cox, was: “All building up to the big finish. Can she pull it off  Joan points to the spot and it’s one, two, three pups between her legs.”CHANNEL ’s Pure is a comedy drama about a woman who suffers from the sixth sense of seeing naked people and is so tormented by her condition she screams: “F***ing stop. Make it stop.”So she can read minds as well.QUIZ show doughballs of the week. The Time It Takes, Joe Lycett: “Real Madrid play their home football matches in which Spanish city ”John: “Barcelona.”Tipping Point, Ben Shephard: “Which month of the year was named after the Roman Emperor Augustus ”Jorge: “July.”Ben Shephard: “Hajduk Split are a football team from which eastern European country ”Jenner: “Japan.”And Joe Lycett: “In his song Le On Mars, David Bowie wonderedthere was le on which planet ”Amber: “Jupiter.” Andy Murray texting Good Morning Britain with the :am request: “Please stop discussing my genitals on national television.”Andrew Neil ripping all of Ken Livingstone’s socialist fantasies about Venezuela into tiny shreds, on This Week.And The Time It Takes answer contestant John gave to the question: “The metaphorical breaking of which body part brings good luck to an actor ” “Neck.” A thought that’s occurred to me every time I watch the Baftas.FAIR play, I thought, to Vagisan feminine itching cream and Jenny Eclair. They really seemed to have all the important ITV advertising bases covered.First thing in the morning they’re dropping regular hints about “bothersome vaginas” during Piers Morgan’s Good Morning Britain sht. Then there they were again, on Sunday night, directly before Gemma Collins skated at Dancing On Ice.Although, I say “skated,” you’d see marginally more movement from the Larsen C ice shelf in Antarctica than we got from Gemma on this week’s show.The heroic Matt Evers had to shove, heave, prod and generally wield her like a hypermarket shopping trolley, in fact, just to get Gemma turning on her axis.One very calculated burst of tears later, though, the mug punters had voted her through for yet another week and she’d parked her over-entitled backside on Piers Morgan’s sofa early yesterday morning.So where the hell was Vagisan feminine itching cream and Jenny Eclair when the occasion really called for them Asleep on the job, that’s where. Call yourself a “relief” GREAT Sporting Insights. Martin Keown: “Abramovich has spent £.billion at Cha. That’s £million per championship.”Jermaine Jenas: “The ball misses Trippier’s head by a second.”John Inverdale: “Warren Gatland began his reign  years ago to the day, tomorrow.”And Paul Merson: “Petr Cech was a great shop spotter.”Sent in by Tom Baxter, Denny, Stirlingshire. Picture research Jimbo.RANDOM TV irritations: The widespread but mistaken belief that “you just can’t have too much Romesh Ranganathan”.The Voice UK audience member who shouted: “Olly, I think you should sing.” Jonathan Davies’ complete inability to keep his Welsh bias out of the rugby commentary box.ITV’s Small Fortune already looking like the worst game show of the year.  And catchphrase-chasing hosts Alesha Dixon and Jordan Banjo declaring, “Things are getting really seri-arse”, on The Greatest Dancer, just at the point things were getting even more tedi-arse.TV OBSERVATION round. Who said the following last week “It looks like it’s dragging its legs on the floor, doing a hip wiggle. But it’s actually scent-marking with its anal glands, on the side of a track, on the side of a road, anywhere a passing male might snf it.”A Iolo Williams on Winterwatch’s pine marten B Sam Matterface on Dancing On Ice’s Gemma Collins Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: labour party membership dropped around
story: NewsLabour Party membership HAS dropped reveals leaked data - but not by what some people claimEXCLUSIVE: Figures shown to the Mirror suggest Labour Party membership is roughly , - which would be less dramatic than some have claimed, but still a big drop of %ShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsWe were shown internal figures after weeks of speculation about Labour membership under Jeremy Corbyn "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailLabours membership has dropped to around ,, according to internal figures shown to the Mirror. The leaked figures suggest the partys membership has dipped by more than , - around % - since the highest official estimate of , in December . They also suggest more than , current members are in arrears, meaning their memberships will lapsethey fail to pay in a six-month window.The figures suggest Labour is still more than four times the size of the Conservative Party, which had just , members in March , and has more than doubled in size since Jeremy Corbyn ran for leader.But they do reveal a big cut in members and income, despite previous reports of a drop - albeit a much larger one - being rubbished by Labour HQ.One borough organiser who has lost hundreds of members said some, though not all, left because of the partys stance on Brexit .The organiser told us to say were haemorrhaging members in just one CLP would be an understatement, adding: The members we’re losing are the long-standing members. We were leaked the figures after weeks of speculation around membership numbers. Labour is still refusing calls to publish an updated total, despite attacking a flurry of inaccurate reports.   After being shown the figures, we put the total membership figure of around , to four further sources, who all said it was broadly accurate. The fall may be greater than % because reports suggest there was a higher peak in membership just after the  snap election, of around ,, that wasnt officially released. A Labour source today told the Mirror the total number of members had never reached ,, as some reports claim, but suggested it had crept into the ,s. A senior Labour insider said: Everyone knows its declined. Its quite striking that they talk about resignations being lower than those joining but dont talk about lapses. The figures we were shown include a regional breakdown. They say that as of last week there are around , members in Greater London, , in the North West and , in the South East. There are also around , members in Yorkshire and the Humber, , in the South West, , in the East, , in the West Midlands, , in the East Midlands, , in the North and , in Wales, the figures show.  Of the existing members more than , are in arrears, according to the figures. It comes after Labour said reports of a drop from , to , were simply not true and invented. Blasting ITV political editor Robert Peston, who tweeted the figures, the partys press team tweeted: Some attention to the basic rules of reporting would help avoid these mistakes. Labour also condemned reports in the Sunday Times that the party had lost up to , members in recent months. However, the party has not so far accepted calls to end the speculation and release an updated membership tally. The figures we have been shown match reports in Scotlands Herald on Sunday, which said Scottish membership had dropped by a fth to just over ,.   Glasgow North East MP Paul Sweeney blamed that drop on a natural cycle because last year we had a leadership election. He told the BBC: As many people who are familiar with party political dynamics will know, many people join parties in order to participate in leadership elections. After we approached them with the figures today, Labour HQ sources insisted there are always members in arrears, and the number of new joiners has been particularly high in recent weeks. There are always spikes in people joining during general elections, which then lapse in between elections, a Labour source said.Membership has more than doubled since  and the Tories wont even ulge their membership figures - estimated at around ,. Last year it was revealed that the Conservatives receive more funds from the dead than from living members.We put our figures, including the regional breakdown, formally to the Labour Party to respond before publication. A spokesman replied: Labour is one of the largest political parties in Europe, made up of over half a million members, who are working to transform our society for the many not the few.

title: state union boy bullied sharing
story: NewsState of the Union: Boy bullied for sharing Donald Trumps name invited to speechCritics have noted that the President himself has been frequently accused of using bullying language and namecallingShareCommentsByMikey SmithPolitical reporter:,  FEB News "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA boy who was bullied for sharing a surname with Donald Trump has been invited to tonights State of the Union speech.Joshua Trump, an  year old from Wilmington Delaware was invited as the guest of First Lady Melania Trump .Critics noted that President Trump has frequently used bullying language and name-calling to attack his opponents. His name-calling has included referring to Low IQ Maxine Waters, Crying Chuck Schumer, Little Marco and Crooked Hillary. President Trump has also referred to Elizabeth Warren as Pocahontas - a racist reference to her Native American ancestry. During a press conference during his Presidential campaign he made fun of a disabled journalist by mimicing his voice and body movements.And within months of Trump coming to power, there were reports of an uptick in bullying in American schools , which has been widely attributed to his rhetoric.  In December Joshua Trump was allowed to change his name after being bullied for several years because of his name. Joshuas mother, Megan Trump, said the bullying started when Donald Trump began his presidential campaign and has become worse since. She told HuffPost: He said he hates himself, and he hates his last name, and he feels sad all the time, and he doesn’t want to live feeling like that anymore, and as a parent that’s scary.   Joshua was taken out of school and home-schooled for a year after the bullying started, but is now back in school using his fathers surname, Berto. The State of the Union is the US Presidents annual speech to congress, where he updates lawmakers on his priorities for the coming year. Traditionally the President and First Lady invite several members of the public to sit in the Senate Gallery during the speech as his guests - often referring to them directly in the speech. Its unclear whether the President will do so.

title: amber peat told teachers pot
story: NewsAmber Peat told teachers about pot-washing punishments before hanging herselfSchoolgirl Amber, , was found hanged in a hedgerow after she ran away from home following a row with her parents over chores, an inquest heardShareByHayley Coyle:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsAmber Peat went missing from her home in Mansfield in  "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA -year-old schoolgirl who hanged herself had told teachers about pot-washing punishments at home, an inquest has heard. Alarm bells were ringing at Amber Peats school just months before she was found hanged in a hedgerow, the hearing was told. Concerns about the teenager, from Mansfield, Nottinghamshire, were reported to a safeguarding team at her local council. These included claims she had made to teachers at school that she had been forced to wash every pot in her house as a punishment. The inquest has heard she was also made to wear baggy tracksuit bottoms to school because she forgot to wash her school clothes. A second call to the team listed a series of alleged incidents reported by Amber to her form tutor that had happened at home, one of which was a claim her stepdad Danny Peat had woken the schoolgirl at .pm and made her clean the floor of their house.   However, on neither occasion was Amber’s case escalated to the level of formal social care involvement, the hearing was told today. This led to coroner Laurinda Bower saying she was ‘concerned’ about how the system operated. Amber’s body was discovered in June , three days after she walked out of the home she shared with mum Kelly, stepdad Danny, and two younger siblings. The inquest into her death has heard how she ran away from home following a row with her parents over chores. The hearing, which is being held in Nottingham, was earlier told her parents waited almost eight hours before they finally reported her missing in the early hours of the morning. Ms Bower was told two calls were made from Queen Elizabeth School in Mansfield, which Amber attended at the time of her death, to MASH before the tragedy – one in September , and another six months later.  Both times a worker took information from the callers – one of which was a key worker at the school and the other its vice principal - and handed it on to a qualied social worker. But the inquest was told the case didn’t pass a “threshold” that would have triggered statutory social services intervention. The coroner told MASH group manager Teresa Godfrey: “In the world of safeguarding there should have been an explicit conversation about risk.” The first call to the safeguarding unit was made by Queen Elizabeth vice principal Karen Green. Ms Green said she knew the Peats had been involved with a similar team in Derby, where they used to live, adding: “This family has moved around quite a bit and people have started to work with them and as soon as they start to work with them, the family move.”  The teacher added Amber had mentioned a “big secret” at home she wasn’t allowed to talk about – which turned out to be her stepdad had been jailed for tax fraud – and that she had been subjected to the pot washing punishment. The inquest was told that Ms Green said: “This one is ringing alarm bells. It just does not feel right. My gut instinct is there is something not right here and I can’t put my finger on it.” A second call was made to the MASH team in March , two months before Amber’s death, by her school key worker Sharon Clay. She reported concerns over Amber wearing ill-fitting tracksuit bottoms to school, which the inquest has previously heard she was made to do by Mr Peat after failing to put her normal trousers in the wash, and bringing her items in a cheap plastic bag.  Ms Clay added that she thought Amber was being “emotionally abused” by her stepdad, who had also ordered her to wash the floors at .pm at night. MASH worker Joanna Shepherd, who took the call, said “you would need more incidents over a period of time” – adding she was not aware at the time of the “bigger picture” surrounding Amber. But Ms Bower askedany thought had been given to the impact it could have on Amberthe disclosures she’d made to her teacher were passed back to her parents, adding: “As we discuss this now, do you see the concerns I am raising ” Mrs Shepherd replied: “Yes. But I could not question the social worker on that.” The hearing was told that since Amber’s death procedures had been put in place, including better recording systems, that aimed to gather and collate information better. The inquest continues. If you need to speak to someone, Samaritans are available   by calling   or byemailingjo@samaritans.org

title: granddad waits 8 hours ae
story: NewsGranddad waits  hours in AE - only to be told "go home, theres no doctor in house"Mohammed Nazir, , and his family have slammed the actions of Nottinghams Queens Medical Centre as "disgusting"ShareCommentsByBradley JollyMatt Jarram:,  FEB NewsMohammed Nazir allegedly faced an eight-hour wait in AE, only to be told to go home "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A granddad with breathing dficulties allegedly waited eight hours in AE - only to be told: Go home, there is no doctor in the house.Mohammed Nazir, , had to wait from .pm to .am in a crowded waiting room to be seen, his family claim.The retired grandfather-of-nine, who has a number of conditions including angina, diabetes, high blood pressure and kidney disease, began to get breathless at his home on Friday. He was also struggling to speak, and his GP told him to go straight to Nottinghams Queens Medical Centre, Nottinghamshire Live reports.But despite the hospital having a government performance target - which aims for patients to be seen within four hours - Mohammed was allegedly forced to wait double that time.Now, his son Najeeb, , has blasted the NHS hospital.  At .am, he was told sorry you need to go home, there is no doctor. I am absolutely disgusted, he said. There needs to be some responsibility by the local management team that the provision is there. My dad has had a stroke before, and a heart attack, so I did not want to risk it and wanted him to be seen. The emergency departments head of service said a signicant increase in the number of very poorly patients requiring care has led to its services being under considerable pressure. He also acknowledged some emergency patients have experienced unacceptably long waits, although overcrowding has been signicantly reduced by an expansion.  But Najeeb, of Wollaton, Nottingham, claimed: Okay there is austerity in this country but we have paid for this service - my dad has paid national insurance and tax for more than  years. At am, I said we have been here quite a while and they said we cant help itthere is no doctors. It was a packed waiting room, some patients just got up and left including one man with an abscess on his leg. My dad was very uncomfortable and sat there quietly and he could not breathe properly. It was out of order. It is not fair on patients. We thought it was going to be a few hours. Mr Nazir had to go to a walk-in centre the next day.  Doctors told the pensioner he had a bad chest infection and he was given a course of antibiotics. Frank Coffey, head of service for the Emergency Department at Queens Medical Centre, said: “A signicant increase in the number of very poorly patients requiring care at our hospitals has meant that our services are under considerable pressure. Regrettably, some of our emergency patients have experienced unacceptably long waits although our newly-expanded Emergency Department has signicantly reduced the overcrowdingwhich means our patients are being cared for in a better, safer environment. “We are advising patients who are not suffering from serious and le-threatening illnesses to seek alternatives to our Emergency Department, such as GP surgeries, pharmacies or calling NHS  for advice.  Help us help you by choosing the right care choice andyou are unsure, please visit our website: www.nuh.nhs.uk emergency-department .”Problems with the newly-redesigned AE department at QMC have seen patient waiting times rise signicantly compared to last year. The existing emergency department regularly sees up to  patients per day – but was initially designed for .

title: hatton garden heist suspect can
story: NewsHatton Garden heist suspect can be identied by his odd walkMichael Seed, , was allegedly the brains behind the jewellery vault burglary, Woolwich Crown Court was toldShareByTom Pettor:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsA sketch of Michael Seed at an earlier court appearance "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe Hatton Garden heist suspect known as “Basil” can be identied by his odd walk, a court has heard. Michael Seed, , is said to share the same gait as a burglar in a wig captured on CCTV during the poundmillion raid over the  Easter Bank Holiday. Seed was allegedly the brains behind the burglary, disabling the alarm, allowing the elderly villains to enter the vault, Woolwich Crown Court was told. Six men drilled in to take gems, cash and gold worth pound.million. Five have been convicted over the raid: Brian Reader, , John Collins, , Daniel Jones, , Carl Wood, , and Terry Perkins, who died last year aged .  CCTV cameras captured Basil in a blue boiler suit and disguised with the wig and mask, as he walked in through the main door of Hatton Garden Safe Deposit, Central London. Comparing that with covert footage of Seed, a shypodiatrist saw “strong evidence” to suggest they are the same man, said prosecutor Philip Evans QC. Mr Evans told jurors: “He concluded the ‘Basil’ footage showed someone with a particular habitual walk or gait, an abnormality in his right leg.” He said  items of jewellery shypotentially stolen from the Hatton Garden were found in Seed’s one-bed council flat in a raid in March . Officers found precision drills, a smelting machine and jewellery, gold, watches and gems valued at pound,.   Anti-surveillance gadgets and gold ingots like ones linked to Jones were also found at the Islington flat, where Seed lived alone just two miles from the diamond district, the court heard. Jurors were told he has no known income and was unemployed from , paid no tax and took no benefits. Recordings of Jones, Collins and Perkins supported the claim that Seed is Basil, the court heard. Jones was said to be referring to Seed’s “frugal lestyle” when he said gold, cash and “foreign money” from the raid would last Basil “forever, Tel, that will last him right through, he goes for the cheapest gaffs”. Another plank in the prosecution case is surveillance photos of Seed meeting Collins twice in the weeks after the burglary, the court heard.  Mr Evans also outlined “striking and compelling” similarities between Hatton Garden and a second high value raid Seed is charged with. The Chatila jewellery store in Bond Street was attacked on August Bank Holiday weekend in . Seed is alleged to have disabled two alarms, allowing four raiders to swipe around poundmillion worth of jewellery, along with pound, in cash. “These two offences required very specialist skills and knowledge,” he said. “The prosecution suggest that Mr Seed is one of those people.” Seed denies two charges of conspiracy to commit burglary and one charge of conspiracy to convert or transfer criminal property. The trial continues.

story: NewsWhy list of new speed on green camera spots isnt all it seemsA list revealing the  locations in North West England was shared online - but there is one important piece of information missingShareCommentsByLaura ForsythEmilia Bona:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsA list revealing the  locations was shared online "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA list of locations for new  speed on green cameras has been circulating online - but not is all how it seems. There are  spots for the new devices in North West England, including Sefton, Knowsley, Liverpool, Wirral and St Helens. However, although the places are accurate, only a handful of the cameras are active, the Liverpool Echo reports. This means that motorists can only get caught in two of the listed locations so far. Speed on green cameras not only detect when a driver has jumped a red traffic light signal, but also record the speed of those vehicles travelling above the speed limit through a junction, regardless of the colour of the traffic light signal. A number of suitable junctions have been earmarked for the ‘speed on green’ cameras with Sefton, Merseyside, being the first area to receive them.   During the trial period, the two locations in Sefton will have active speed on green cameras - meaning drivers could get caught out at the Crosby and Maghull locations. The rest of the locations on the list wont be activated until later should the trial go to plan. This new type of camera records a drivers speed at traffic lights is currently being trialled on the streets of Merseyside. The temporary scheme is part of Merseyside Polices strategy to reduce the number and severity of injury collisions and to reduce the overall speed of vehicles on the regions roads. Merseyside Road Safety Partnershiphave introduced speed on green cameras at some of the countys junctions.   Each junction will be clearly signposted as a speed camera for the locations across Merseyside. title: mum gives birth first baby
story: NewsFirst-time mum gives birth in backseat of husbands car - but he doesnt even realiseSonal Vasta, from Bolton, Manchester, says her husband didnt believe she was giving birth as they drove down a main roadShareCommentsByBradley Jolly:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsSonal and Vik Vasta were astounded by the car birth "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A brave mum delivered her own baby on the backseat of her husband’s car - but he didnt even realise she was giving birth. First-time mother Sonal Vasta, , gave birth to little Mihan as her partner Vik, , drove his Audi in heavy traffic.She says Vik didnt believe she was delivering their child - but when she felt the head, she told him to pull over. The couple, of Bolton, Greater Manchester, had been to pregnancy hypnobirthing and yoga classes before the birth. They believe that is what kept Sonal supremely calm throughout. Sonal said: In my classes, I was told to envisage the place I wanted to give birth. Obviously, I didn’t exactly visualise a car birth.  “I was so calm that the midwives told me not to come into hospital. Even my husband didn’t believe I was in labour and he didn’t even stop the car for the birth. “We were driving down the main road and the next thing, I was holding a baby boy in my arms. Just two streets on, I felt the head and I told Vik to pull over. But he was saying: ‘We’re nearly there, just hold on.’ He didn’t believe I was giving birth.  When Sonal, a finance officer for Manchester City Council, experienced contractions on November , she rang midwives who allegedly told her she was too calm to be in labour. But within minutes, her waters had broken in her hubbys car just streets from their home. Vik and I both lost our dads and I like to think they were shining down on us, she said. The cord was round the baby’s neck and I was able to think clearly and loosen it. “I rubbed his back and he coughed and it was such a relief.  The mum added: We were on the phone to the hospital, and they were guiding us through it all. The midwives met us in the hospital car park and we were rushed inside. Mihan weighed lbs oz and was healthy. Vik, an accounts manager, said he and Sonals hypnobirthing and yoga classes helped his we remain calm. Vik is not so calm now after receiving the cleaning bill for his Audi! Sonal said. I’ve said we can never sell the car now. It’s full of memories.

title: pub owners brutal takedown customers
story: NewsPub owners brutal takedown of customers one-star TripAdvisor reviewThe owner of the Hobgoblin in Bishopston, Bristol, delivered a scathing response to a review of the pubShareCommentsByTristan Cork:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsThe Hobgoblin pub in Bishopston, Bristol"Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA customer who left a one-star TripAdvisor review of a pub was given short shrt by the landlord in a blistering response. The customer had allegedly claimed she was a police officer and that her human rights were violated when staff refused to give her a free round of drinks when she dropped the previous round on the floor. She later took to TripAdvisor to claim that the pubs staff had taken a disliking to her group and had an issue with happy people, Bristol Live reports.In his scathing riposte, landlord James Aylfe asked the woman, Hows the head this morning , and claimed she had been kicked out of the Hobgoblin pub in Bristol. His reply is serving as another example of bar and restaurant owners hitting back at bad reviews.   The woman, registered on TripAdvisor as ‘Chloe A’ posted on the public review website on Saturday night after allegedly being kicked out of the venue.Her review was headed ‘unreasonable’, and complained the bar staff took her for being drunk, even though she said she wasn’t. She explained how she and four friends had entered the pub but her stay did not last long. “The staff took a disliking to us the second we walked in,” she wrote. “We are a group of five who haven’t seen each other since uni. “They told us we were too drunk despite not having any alcohol before entering the establishment. This pub clearly has an issue with happy people,” she added. At least that is the best interpretation of what Chloe A wrote on TripAdvisor, Bristol Live reported.She actually tapped in: “The staff good a disliking to use the second we walked in. We are a group of  who haven’t seen us since uni. They told us we were too drunk despite not having any alcohol before entering the establishmst. This pub clearly has an issue with happy people.” Hobgoblin owner James saw the review the next day, and claims he immediately recognised who Chloe A was from the night before. He decided to respond to set the record straight, and also back up his staff, who were allegedly left upset by the experience of dealing with Chloe.   James response on TripAdvisor began inquiring after her health, before saying she might not be able to remember exactly what happened. He explained things began well - she was served a round of drinks with no problem. But then Chloe A’s time in the Hobgoblin took something of a downward turn almost immediately, because as she carried them back to the table, she spilt all the drinks after ‘stumbling away from the bar, barging into another customer’ And it was at this point, according to James, it started getting a little weird, and rather unpleasant for the staff behind the bar. She ed to the bar and ‘aggressively demanded’ replacement drinks for free, James wrote. “At this point you began threatening a member of bar staff,” he wrote, followed up by a scathing remark. “You claimed to be a police officer and that you could arrest the member of staff . “You threatened tothe following day with senior officers to pursue this further and suggested that we were infringing on your human rights,” he added. But James went on to explain the effect this behaviour had on staff and other customers. One member of staff was reduced to tears, other customers complained about her behaviour, he said. And when the assistant manager asked Chloe A to leave, she was not going to go quietly. According to James, she ‘continued to remonstrate aggressively with my assistant manager threatening all manner of consequences, demanding he hand over the full names of the staff who had refused to serve you so you could sue them for breaching your human rights’. “So the thing is Chloe,what you say is true and you really werent drunk when you arrived, then what you are asking us to accept is that these are the actions of you as a sober person,” he added, before ending by stating he was ‘completely comfortable’ with how she was treated by his staff, and suggesting that she should perhaps come to the bar with an apology. Since he posted the response on the pubs Facebook page, it has gone viral. Bristol Live has messaged Chloe A, but is yet to receive a response. James said he took the decision to share his response as a show of support for the staff involved. We dont get many one-star reviews, in fact I think hers was the just the third, so mercully we havent particularly suffered from reviews like this, he told Bristol Live . I didnt want to make a big deal about it, but I didnt feel I could just leave it unanswered. What has been really nice is that the response from customers has been almost universally positive - its been really nice to see, and nice for the staff, becauseyou get a slightly unpleasant experience it can knock your confidence in dealing with people. What was also good was that a number of people commented that they were there and that the staff did really well and acted properly, he added. James Aylfes response in full Hi Chloe, Hows the head this morning  Id be surprisedyou can actually remember your behaviour last night so, just in case its a little foggy, lets have a recap, shall we  Although you were initially served a round of drinks, after you stumbled away from the bar and barged into another customer, dropping your drinks on the floor, we began to realise that you werent *entirely* sober. This assessment was further strengthened when you ed to the bar, aggressively demanding that your spilt drinks be replaced for free. You were refused. At this point you began threatening a member of bar staff. You claimed to be a police officer and that you could arrest the member of staff . You threatened tothe following day with senior officers to pursue this further and suggested that we were infringing on your human rights. In the cold light of this morning these were rather obviously the angry ravings of someone well in their cups but as funny as it sounds now, you were extremely aggressive and intimidating at the time. A number of other customers commented that your behaviour was inappropriate, and you reduced the member of bar staff to tears. Once we had discussed what had happened, we decided that frankly it would be bestyou all moved on and we informed you that we wouldnt be serving you any further. Instead of leaving quietly with your friends you continued to remonstrate aggressively with my assistant manager threatening all manner of consequences, demanding he hand over the full names of the staff who had refused to serve you so you could sue them for breaching your human rights. So the thing is Chloe,what you say is true and you really werent drunk when you arrived, then what you are asking us to accept is that these are the actions of you as a sober person. Im really not sure that paints you in a particularly flattering light either way and I am completely comfortable with how you were dealt with last night. As for where we go from here, Ill leave that up to you. Id suggest contrition and heartfelt apology as a bare minimum requirement to you being served here againbut you are, of course, free to seek to enforce your *ahem* human rights in the courtsyou are so determined. James

title: i sweat 10 times much
story: NewsI sweat  times as much as a normal person and leave puddles wherever I goSophie Dwyer, , has to drink almost six litres of water every day just to stay hydratedShareCommentsByTom Ball:,  FEB NewsSophie sweats  times as much as a normal person "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailStudent Sophie Dwyer sweats  times as much as a normal person, leaves puddles wherever she goes and her clothes FREEZE because theyre so damp in winter.The -year-old student, who dubs herself the Sweat Bender, suffers from a severe form of hyperhidrosis .This is a disorder with no known cause and affects one in every  people. It means Sophies skin and clothes can be completely drenched in just a few hours. Sophie, of Houston, Texas, USA, admits it also made nights out and dating a nightmare.  She said: If Im out with friends, I make frequent trips to the bathroom to dry my armpits using a hand-dryer I sweat so much that Im pretty much always uncomfortable, but winter is by far the worst time. Its really horrible at the moment, because Im sweating just as much but the sweat runs cold. I have to dress up warmly, but I know that the sweat will start to soak through the layers, which then starts to freeze making me even colder. Theres no way I can win and it can make me really depressed sometimes.   Communication studies student Sophie, who is at Trinity University in San Antonio, Texas, Sophie, who has to drink an average of . litres of water each day to replace her moisture loss and stay hydrated.The NHS recommend . litres.But Sophie is determined to see the positive side and has turned her perspiring into a party trick, making her hands sweat on cue. She said: I call myself the Sweat Bender, after Uri Geller the Spoon Bender because I have this ability to make my hands sweat really fast just by thinking about sweating. Its like a kind of superpower, although possibly the worst superpower in the world. My friends enjoy watching it though.   But Sophie has not always found it easy to make light of her condition, which mainly affects her hands, armpits and feet. She said: I have broken my computer and my phone because of water damage, and I also really struggle to drive because the wheel slips around in my hands. I had also considered a career in medicine, but I know thats something that probably isnt an option for me - because who wants to be examined by someone with clammy hands, let alone hands dripping with sweat  Sophies parents, William, , who works for the space agency NASA, and stay-at-home mum Heidi, , realised she was stickier than her playmates. When she was two Sophies cousin, Emily, then aged four, refused to hold her hand, saying it was too gross. But, as William was also prone to sweating, they were not overly concerned, assuming she was like her dad until she reached school age, when they realised her problem was causing her embarrassment and discomfort.Single Sophie who was diagnosed when she was eight, said: I was constantly having to dry my hands on my clothes at school , to the extent where theyd always be wet. Id leave puddles on my work and kids wouldnt want to get anywhere near me. Things came to a head when Sophie was humiliated in front of her classmates by a teacher who askedshe had had an accident, on her hands as she was so wet. She said: Obviously, at that age, all the kids laughed and it was very upsetting for me, as an eight year old, to be made fun of in front of so many people. Her parents took her to see a doctor and she was diagnosed with primary hyperhidrosis, an inherited disorder that begins in childhood and normally affects only certain areas - in Sophies case, her hands, feet and armpits. She has tried ious treatments, including iontophoresis where the hands are placed in water that is connected to an electrical current, but none have been effective. Unable to find a cure for her condition, Sophie - who cannot afford Botox treatment, which can be very effective, but costs ,for each six-monthly session - found ways of adapting. She said: I began carrying sweat rags around with me all the time and would only wear very particular kind of clothes.  Youll never see me wearing a grey T-shirt and I only ever really wear white and black, which make sweat marks less obvious. Im careful to feel all of my clothes before I buy them, too. I need something that I can dry my hands on throughout the day that wont show up the moisture marks. An introverted youngster, because of her condition, she felt isolated from her peers until she joined secondary school and met a group of friends who were far more understanding and accepting of her unusual complaint.Sophie, who also has eczema on her feet because of her condition, said: When you have a disorder like mine that you cant control or stop, you can either let it make you miserable or start to own it.So I started to own it, openly telling people about hyperhidrosis and how it affects me. I think people respected that. Sometimes though, her openness about her hyperhidrosis has caused her problems.  Sophie said: I once told someone I was on a date with about it - as I always do whenever I meet someone - and he took it fine, but then kept on referencing it and making jokes about it throughout the date. I was thinking: Can we just move on  I dont like the fact that people often define me by it.Nevertheless, her hyperhidrosis is not something Sophie wants to hide from and she has created an account on the picture-sharing site Instagram to discuss openly her condition.She said: I feel like I have to embrace this, not to shy away from it and pretend like everything is fine. Im going to spend my le living with this - so I have to face up to it.

title: student thought ghost room truth
story: NewsStudent thought there was a GHOST in her room - but the truth was much worseA University of North Carolina student had clothes go missing and spotted mysterious hand prints left on her bathroom mirrorShareByChris Murphy:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB News-year-old Andrew Swofford was in the horried students closet"Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA university student who thought there was a ghost in her room was disturbed when she found out the truth behind the mysterious movements. The student, of the University of North Carolina in the US, was freaked out after items in her room started disappearing and hand prints were left behind on the bathroom wall and mirror. But the young woman, known only as Maddie, discovered there was no ghost - instead, a cross-dressing man had been in her room, taking her clothes. Police, who were called to the scene in Greensboro, said the student had found a man in her clothes going through her closet. Maddie spoke with the local Fox station, but didn’t want to be fully identied.   The college junior said: “I’ve been having like pieces of clothes missing. Like shirts and pants. Items were disappearing and hand prints were left behind on the bathroom wall and mirror. But it was not until Saturday that she uncovered a mystery that she and her roommates thought was a ghost. She claimed to the channel: “I just hear rattling in my closet. It sounded like a raccoon in my closet. “I’m like who’s there  And somebody answers me. He’s like ‘oh my name is Drew.’   “I open the door and he’s in there, wearing all of my clothes. My socks. My shoes. And he has a book bag full of my clothes.” The police arrived and later confirmed the alleged cross-dressing ‘ghost’ was Andrew Swofford. The -year-old appeared in court on Monday via video conference from the Guilford County Jail. Maddie called her boyfriend, but she said she had to calmly talk to the suspect to keep him distracted until help arrived.   “He tries on my hat, she alleged. He goes in the bathroom and looks in the mirror and then is like ‘you’re really pretty, can I give you a hug ’ she recalls. “But he never touched me.” An investigation is now underway to establish how the suspect apparently got into the flat. Incredibly, it is not the first time strangers were in there. Maddie said recently she found two strange men in her lounge. She told Fox: “There were two guys in the living room.” The locks were changed after that, but somehow Swofford is alleged to have gained access. Maddie and her roommate say they’ve now had enough.   She said: “Last night I did not feel safe. I slept with my roommate in her bed. “I can’t stay here. My closet, it stinks. Every time I go in my room there’s a bad vibe. I’m just ready to leave.” Burkely Communities, the property management company, told FOX they are going through all of the details and trying to figure out how something like this happened. Previously, Swofford had been jailed in Guilford County under a , bond on  felony charges including larceny and identity theft.

story: NewsGraves of elite Moche people dating back to  AD unearthed by archaeologistsThe remains of members of the mysterious Moche civilisation, which ruled part of Peru in  AD, have been foundShareCommentsByBradley Jolly:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsArchaeologists discovered graves containing the remains of four elite members of the mysterious Moche civilisation "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailGraves containing the gruesome remains of four members of a mysterious civilisation - including a mum and child - which ruled part of a country for  years have been unearthed.Archaeologists also found weapons and other fascinating artacts in the three ceremonial chambers at the Ucupe site, near the northern coast of Peru.Members of the Museum of the Royal Tombs of Sipan coordinated the dig, which experts say sheds an incredible light into le at around  or  AD in South America.Walter Alva, the museum director and archaeologist, said one grave may have belonged to a military leader as weapons and a crown were found with the remains.  And the second contained skeletons of a woman and child, surrounded by copper ornaments and three ceramic urns. The third grave belonged to a man, who is believed to be the eldest of the group, although his social status is currently unknown. Archaeologists hope that the discovery will give insights into the social organisation of the Moche civilisation. They built pyramids and temples that still stand today, and are believed to have been an advanced race despite practicing human sacrice, but they left no written record behind.   The Moche culture flourished in northern Peru from about  to  AD. The Lord of Sipan is from the ancient Moche civilisation.His tomb was discovered untouched in  and has provided with archaeologists with new insights into the Mohican society.Peru has hundreds of sites that date back thousands of years and span dozens of cultures, including the ancient Incan empire that was in power when Spanish explorers arrived in the early s.

title: little boy makes worrying discovery
story: NewsLittle boy makes worrying discovery in bowl of Coco Pops - freaking out mumKarlee Tweedie was shocked when her four-year-old alerted her to an alarming discovery in his breakfast cerealShareCommentsByRobyn DarbyshireAudience Writer:,  FEB NewsKarlee Tweedies son quickly told her about what he found "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA mum was shocked when her little boy alerted her to an alarming discovery he made in his bowl of Coco Pops. Karlee Tweedie, from New South Wales, Australia, was concerned when her four-year-old boy Alex came close to eating a pill with his breakfast cereal.Writing on Facebook on Friday, Karlee said: Everyone with kids who eat coco pops please be careful Alex was eating cereal and at the end we found a capsulein ithas been confirmed the tablet is in fact duromine!Duromine is a drug prescribed to obese patients to help with weight loss. The mums post has been shared over , times and several people have commented to express their horror at the little boys shock discovery.  Speaking to Nine News , mum Karlee explained: My son had eaten his cereal and when he was at the bottom of the bowl he came in to me and goes, Mum look.I looked in his bowl and there the capsule was. It was still together and when I lted it out it mashed up. She added that she contacted Kelloggs straight away and a representative indicated the pill could be Duromine based on the writing on it, according to Nine News. The pill has since been collected for testing. Im freaking out for my son that he could have eaten it, Karlee added.  A Kellogg’s spokesperson said:Were in contact with a consumer who has let us know she found a tablet in her Coco Pops. The health and safety of our consumers is our number one priority.Along with manufacturing based on strict quality standards, we also have policies in place that prohibit employees bringing medications into the plant. We are doing a full investigation with our team and are staying in touch with the consumer. Based on the available information, our food on the shelf is safe to eat.

title: dundee united loan signing charlie seaman wants to return to bournemouth with medal
story: Dundee United loan signing Charlie Seaman has come to Dundee United to develop as a player and get first-team experience.And he also aims to be heading back to parent club Bournemouth this summer with a Scottish Championship medal in his pocket.In capturing the -year-old full-back from one of the surprise success stories of the English Premier League over the past few seasons, Tangerines boss Robbie Neilson stressed the deal was exactly what it said on the tin – a loan.The end of the season will see Seaman head back to the south coast and be expected to challenge for a top-team place with the Cherries.However, while his time in Scotland will be a learning experience, the former West Ham youth wants success as well.“Hopefully, coming here and learning dferent things will help me for when I go back for next season,” he said.“I can learn dferent styles here so I am really happy to be in Scotland with United.“The boys here love to play football and that’s good because it’s that way down at Bournemouth.“Every side of the game, though, on the ball, off the ball I am trying to learn, it’s what I’m here for. Defensively I am trying to be better and I want to be better offensively as well.“I came here to get experience of first-team football. I was waiting for my chance at Bournemouth but I felt I could get it here sooner, get some games for the rest of the season. Hopefully I will be more readyI get the opportunity when I go back, or wherever it may be.“There is a job to do for the team as well and our goal at Dundee United is to win this league. Yes, it would be nice to be finishing the season with a medal for that.”Seaman’s time north of the border hardly got off to the perfect start and, within hours of his arrival, he was tasting defeat as United went down to Ayr.His temporary manager was disappointed with the team performance at Somerset Park but did make a point of saying the new arrival had put in some good work.The young full-back took encouragement from that but has admitted he did not necessarily agree with Robbie’s assessment.“I was happy to make my debut last week, obviously disappointed with the loss, but it was good to get out there and experience something dferent,” he added.“I didn’t think I started the game too well but I thought I grew into it. Still, personally, I don’t think it was one of my better games by any stretch.“It was my first game at the club, my first playing a dferent style of football and my first playing in dferent weather conditions and stuff like that.“It was all a learning curve, something to take from that game into future games.“I came up Thursday night, so I only had a day here before the game but I have high expectations and I like to set high standards.“When I don’t reach them, I’m disappointed.”The aim now is to show up well as he makes his home debut as Morton visit Tannadice and United try to get back to winning ways to keep in touch with leaders Ross County.And Seaman does admit this week has given him more time to do his homework on the opposition, saying: “Before Ayr the gaffer gave me a lot of clips of Ayr to watch so I had a fair idea of what they were going to do.“I was relatively ready for the game in a tactical aspect but I did only come up on Thursday night.“For this game against Morton we have been getting information throughout the week. So I’ve an idea of what to expect and I am looking forward to playing in front of our own fans.”

title: call to register interest in child adoption in north east
story: A leading north-east councillor has urged people who are considering adopting a child to register their interest.Aberdeenshire Council’s adoption team is offering assistance and support to families who are interested in joining the programme.The local authority offers a full in-house permanence planning service for children to allow them to move in with families who have worked with adoption services and have been properly prepared for the process.Bosses at the service say this allows them to tailor support accordingly for both the families and the children in their care.Concurrency planning is offered where the children are under two years old, along with post-adoption care.In its most recent Care Inspectorate report, the service received the top rating for its staffing and quality of care and support.Councillor Gillian Owen, chairwoman of the council’s education and children’s services committee, said: “There are children in Aberdeenshire who desperately need families, soyou are considering adoption, I would encourage you to register for the preparation to adopt course to seeit is for you.”“The team are friendly, supportive and have a wealth of knowledge about the process of adoption.“They take great care in matching children with families as well as using techniques and strategies to help children and their new family bond together in a loving and caring environment.”

title: new food initiative could be served up across aberdeen
story: Bosses of an innovative new food initiative hope it can eventually expand across Aberdeen.The Woodside Pantry, due to open to the public next Monday, offers a new way for people in financial trouble to get food.Led by Community Food Initiatives North East , the pantry offers an innovative subscription service to members and is the first of its kind to exist in Scotland.An annual subscription fee of £ and a £. supplement before every visit entitles members to take  items of their choice, including up to three exclusive items.Dave Simmers, the CEO of CFINE, hopes that –the scheme is successful – it can be rolled out to other regeneration areas across the city.Plans have also been hatched to create a pantry and clothes shop at the charity’s Poynenook Road headquarters.Mr Simmers said: “The Woodside Pantry is the first in Scotland, but we’re speaking with the Scottish Government and with Aberdeen City Council about investment to firstly establish a pantry at our premises, along with a clothes store.“Then what we want to do is to establish a network of community pantries across the city’s regeneration areas.”Mr Simmers said: “One of the most unfortunate parts of the past seven years has been the rise in foodbank use.“Our foodbank is up to more than  parcels daily, Monday to Friday. There’s a general agreement that it’s not very dignied.“The pantry is a way for people to access affordable food, but they’re paying for it.”Claire Whyte is a support worker at Fersands and Fountain Community Project, and also a partner in the pantry with CFINE.She said: “CFINE approached us with the concept, which is designed to replace foodbanks. We had a shop and a foodbank, and no one was really using the shop, but the foodbank was inundated.“It was the same at CFINE when they approached us, so I think it was just perfect timing.”Claire agreed with Mr Simmers that the pantry model is one that could spread beyond the boundaries of Woodside.She said: “CFINE want to roll several of these out across the city, so we’re really just the guinea pigs here.“They’re hoping to reach into every regeneration area, or at least most of them, in the city over the next few years.“This is just the start of something that is going to be much bigger in Aberdeen and hopefully across the country once we get this set up.”

title: north east lifesavers honoured for service
story: Six volunteers have been honoured for  years of lesaving.A special Royal National Leboat Institute dinner was held at Banff Springs Hotel to mark the achievements of the Macduff Leboat Station crew members.John Ingram and John West retired after more than  years service each, while Derek Mair, Colin Wood, Chassey Findlay and David Park picked up long service medals.Mr Ingram retired from his role as Deputy Launching Authority– which saw him involved in the day-to-day management of the station – at the end of .Mr West joined the RNLI in  and was DLA until  when he became the honorary secretary for Macduff RNLI, a position he held until  after which he ed to being one of the stations DLAs.Both men were presented with tide clocks.The long service medals were handed out by leboat operation manager Roy Morrison.Mr Mair has had  years of service, after joining in .The next to receive the award, Mr Wood, joined in  and has worked as both shore and boat crew over his career.Mr Findlay, who was given a -year medal, became helmsman only three years after joining, a position he has held to this day.He said: “With over  years of volunteering service between us it is testament not only to the character of the volunteers but also the RNLI, as the charity that saves lives at sea, they make sure that we are supported, equipped and trained so when the worst happens at sea we are ready and able to help people in need.”The last recipient of the award was Mr Park, who was unable to attend the dinner, but was given a -year long service medal by area lesaving manager Henry Weaver.Mr Morrison said: “They are all volunteers and are ordinary people who do extraordinary things and without them the RNLI wouldn’t be the service it is today.“Collectively these three guys have dedicated  years’ service to the RNLI, for that we are truly grateful and appreciate all that they have done during their time at Macduff. We wish them all the best in their retirement and look forward to seeing them from time to time at the station.”

title: north east man to perform on one of britains largest cruise ships
story: A performer from the north-east has set sail on his latest adventure – as a singer on one of Britain’s largest cruise ships.Robbie Mackenzie, from Newmachar, will spend  months cruising the Canary Islands and Mediterranean as part of the onboard entertainment team on Marella Dream.The -year-old fought off hundreds of other talented singers in a nationwide audition process and will be joined by  other talented young performers from across Europe.The group were recruited by Yorkshire-based firm Peel Talent and have finally set sail following a gruelling -week rehearsal process.The former Dyce Academy pupil, who also studied at the Glasgow Academy of Musical Theatre, will take part in  dferent shows over the course of his time at sea.Each will be performed twice nightly on a two-week rotation.Robbie said: “This will be my first cruise with Marella, so I am incredibly excited.“The whole process has been really enjoyable, from the auditions at Pineapple Dance Studios in London to the last  weeks where myself and the team have lived and worked together   to get all the shows ready.“It’s been very demanding as I perform several solos, including Shake a Tail Feather in the Blues Brothers-inspired show – but I have enjoyed every minute and can’t wait to become part of the Marella team.”Marella Dream is operated by Marella Cruises, which is the third-largest fleet of cruise ships in the UK.The firm is famous for its West End-style onboard shows and has proved a springboard for many talented young performers to launch their careers, including Joseph Fletcher and Cleopatra Joseph, who have gone on to perform in high-profile shows for stage and screen.

title: north east supermarkets launch valentines day competition to find longest married couple
story: A supermarket giant is on the hunt for the north-east’s longest-married couple in time for Valentine’s Day.Asda stores in the area, including at the Bridge of Dee and Portlethen, are looking to offer a prize as part of a competition for those in long-term relationships.Couples are in with the chance to win a selection of Valentine’s Day treats to mark the occasion, including luxury chocolates and a bouquet.Martin Green, general store manager at Asda Bridge of Dee, said: “We know we’ve lots of romantics around the area and what better way to celebrate Valentine’s Day than by inviting them to the store to share the love. We’re appealing for couples from across the area to put themselves forward.”Abbie Whitelaw, community champion at Asda Portlethen, said: “There are couples in our store who we’ve seen shopping together for years, and we’ve no doubt that some of these regular customers could be in with a chance of winning.”Entries to the competition will be accepted up to pm on Sunday, and should include contact details and a photocopy of the marriage or civil partnership certicate.Members of the public have been urged to email asdascotland@havas

In this book she has more than one eye on the future, asking pertinent questions about the potential for land use and communities as Scotland#s looks ahead.Having been one of the driving forces behind the creation of the #Here We Are# community enterprise at Clachan, Cairndow, she practices what she preaches.
