title: ayr rugby club near move
story: NewsAyr Rugby Club near move to new town centre base at Dam Park as they prepare to sell Millbrae homeThe Millbrae men, who top the Tennents Premiership, are in advanced talks to sell their Millbrae home and move to Dam Park in Ayr town centre.ShareByStuart Wilson:,  OCT NewsDam Park could play host to Ayr Rugby Club as soon as  "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBooming Ayr Rugby Club are nearing a deal to sell their Millbrae home and move to the town centre. Plans to buy council-owned Dam Park are at an advanced stage. The club, currently top of the Tennent’s Premiership, hope the bold switch will take them to the next level. Ayr would earn a multi-million pound jackpot by hiving off their own land for housing, with builder Cala Homes believed to be preferred bidder for the site. And they plan to use part of the cash for a pound, synthetic surface to be laid at their new home. Club chiefs have spent the last year in talks over a move and hope to seal the deal soon.  If the switch is rubber-stamped by South Ayrshire Council Ayr could be playing out of Dam Park as early as . One source said: “It is the move that makes sensethe club is to continue growing. “Next season sees the start of the Super Six set-up with games to be broadcast live on television. “It is potentially a great  for Ayr and bringing the club into the heart of the town can benefit so many.” The switch would see Ayr Seaforth Athletic Club on the move to a new sporting centre planned for Craigie. And junior side Whitletts Victoria couldto the heart of their community with a revamp of the old activity complex on the cards. Ayr rugby supremo Billy McHarg said talks on the move are progressing well.  He said: “Discussions to this point have been positive. “We’re keen to work with all parties to find the right solution and one which will benefit the whole town. “We feel that Ayr Rugby Club coming into the town centre would be a big step forward.” Club members would still have to approve such a move. Ayr have been at scenic Millbrae since . Prior to that they played out of Newton Park, Dam Park, the Old Racecourse and King George V playing fields. Whitletts chairman John Dalton said: “Talks have been very positive and we are currently looking at alternative options. “The football park at Whitletts is the obvious route to go down and would represent ahome to our roots. “A lot of water is still to go under the bridge but as Ayr’s junior football club we are viewing this as a positive opportunity.” Craigie councillor Ian Cavana said: “It may be that a deal is close but nobody will be moving anywhere until the new sports centre at Craigie is up and running. “Work is due to start on that next summer and that’s when we should see real progress.” A council spokesman said: “Discussions on the future of Dam Park are ongoing.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnSouth Ayrshire CouncilAyr NewsAyrAyr Rugby

title: ayr united 2 inverness 3
story: NewsAyr United  Inverness : John Roberston hails Somerset Park among best grounds in worldThe Inverness gaffer was full of praise for the old fashioned surroundings as his side clung on in the face of a stirring fightback.ShareByStuart Wilson:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsNathan Austin puts Caley - up "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailJohn Robertson hailed Somerset Park as one of the best grounds in the WORLD after Caley held off a storming Ayr fightback. Inverness were three up and on easy street after a crazy opening  minutes which saw United gt-wrap the game. But a Lawrence Shankland inspired comeback almost grabbed a share of the spoils for Ian McCalls title contenders. A relieved Robertson said: Had it finished - you wouldnt have been surprised. Somerset Park is one of these grounds that sucks you inyou give them a snf. Its a good throwback and their fans make it intimidating and a good atmosphere for teams when you lose a goal. Its brilliant...one of the best grounds in the world to come and play your football. In the past we might have lost a game like this so Im delighted.  Ayr knew a win here would take them top of the Championship and started well with Robbie Crawford missing a good chance in the first minute. But they soon hit the self destruct button as their defence went AWOL to allow Nathan Austin in for a double before Liam Polworth rammed home a third. The game looked over with barely  minutes on the clock and shellshocked Ayr took time to regroup. Coventry-bound Michael Rose rocked the post with a header before Michael Moffat drew a fingertip save from Cammy Mackay. McCall turned to the bench at half time and introduced top gun Shankland who immediately turned the tide. He set up Declan McDaid to haul Ayr back into the contest with a close range finish eight minutes after the restart. And a resurgent Ayr thought they had a penalty when Carl Tremarco appeared to handle in the box but ref Nick Walsh waved away loud protests. United continued to pour forward as the clock ticked down and Shankland set up a grandstand finish when slamming home a  yard free kick with five minutes left.  But their comeback proved too little too late as Inverness clung on. Ayr boss McCall said: Im just gutted. Weve conceded three goals and at least two of them were gted with just crazy defending. And were the team with the best defensive record in the league. I think a draw would’ve been fair but it’s just one of those nights. It’s a dficult one to take to get beat.They’re a big strong team and at times we didn’t cope with that.Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnAyrAyr NewsAyr United FC

title: bob shields national trust who
story: NewsBob Shields: National Trust owe an apology over asking people for donations to restore Burns CottageShareByGary Fanning:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsBurns Cottage needs restoration"Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailI’m trying to imagine the back-slapping and glad-handing at the National Trust For Scotland’s Hermiston Quay headquarters when someone came up with a spfing ‘Save Burns Cottage’ wheeze. “Let’s send out a begging letter to all those with Burns Cottage closest to their hearts – the people of Ayr . . .” “Wonderful idea!” “We could arrange for it to land on their doorsteps on Burns birthday – January  . . .” “That’s genius!” “Throw in some pictures of cracked walls and the dodgy thatched roof . . . “ “Fantastic!” “Use phrases like “before it’s too late” – or “damaged beyond repair” . . . “It’s heartbreaking!” “That’s Burns Cottage sorted then! Gin and tonic anyone ” “Large ones all round!” To be serious though – I still can’t decide what made me angrier. The crass begging bowl letter – hoping to cash in on the biggest Burns day of the year  Or the fact that Burns Cottage has been allowed to fall into such a state that phrases like “damaged beyond repair” are even necessary  If we’re talking man’s insensitivity to man here – then last Friday’s NTS letter takes the bannock! Its contents have upset dozens of people I know – and judging by the reaction on social media, hundreds more that I don’t know. Nicky Cotter wrote: “NTS . . . put your hands in your pockets and get it fixed. If you can spend pound, on a wooden tree house at Culzean Castle – you can stump up pound, to fix one of the most historically and culturally signicant buildings in Scotland”. Spot on, sir. The NTS letter tells us that “time and Scotland’s wet winters have taken their toll”. Yes – that’ll be the  winters since Burns father William Burness built the cottage on . And during that period, it’s been thatched more times than Wayne Rooney’s balding napper. If the current thatch “has signicant tears and has worn away”, you have to askthe last thatching work was in some way inferior - orthe cottage needed re-thatched several years ago and the work was never undertaken  You then start wondering how the auld clay biggin’ managed to survive the  wet Scottish winters between the cottage being built and the National Trust for Scotland’s formation back in   The answer is fairly obvious. Back then – people looked after it! And you only have to look at the recent row over the deteriorating Burns Monument to start wonderingthe NTS is the right custodian of our Burns heritage  Burns Cottage is everything Mr Cotter said earlier . .. and more. It’s the most important building in Ayrshire – by a lang Scots mile. Every nook, cranny - and twig of its roof - should be the subject of a fingertip, annual inspection. And whatever work is required – at whatever cost – should be sanctioned immediately. In fact, I imagine that’s what ‘most people’ thought was already happening. But then we had last Friday’s mail . . . when ‘most people’ discovered to their horror that the north-west gable is starting to pull away from the rest of the cottage! If admission fees don’t cover the cost of Burns Cottage – then put them up! The last figures I have show , visitors in . Charging them an extra p would have reached the pound, required – with enough left over to putty the windows as well. So, I’m sorry, NTS. But this was the wrong letter . . . to the wrong people . . . on the wrong day. You owe a lot of honest men and a lot of bonnie lassies an apology!Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnAyr

title: driver who sped 70mph through
story: NewsDriver who sped at mph through streets of Troon is jailed for  monthsMark Kirkby almost killed his passenger when he finally crashed into a wall following the high speed chase.ShareByAyrshire Post:,  FEB NewsMark Kirkby was jailed for the reckless driving"Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA man who drove like a maniac through the streets of Troon has been jailed for  months, writes Edwin Lawrence. Mark Kirkby, , almost killed passenger Kerrie Anne Monaghan when he finally crashed into a wall. Miss Monaghan was in Ayr Sherf Court on crutches to hear the sentence on her partner, who she is standing by. The court heard Kirkby did not even have a driving licence and Sherf John Montgomery banned him from holding one for four years. Depute fiscal Lindsay Bain told the court police spotted a silver Volvo being driven erratically from Barassie Street into Portland Street. The police car’s blue lights went on and Kirkby initially slowed down before increasing speed. He was hitting mph in Templehill before heading into Harbour Road. And Kirkby’s car was said to have taken off as he drove across a mini roundabout into Port Ranald Drive. He hit mph in North Shore Road, eventually crashing into a wall at the Beach Road Kilmarnock Road junction in Barassie. During the whole episode, which began around .am on October  last year, Kirkby drove dangerously through junctions and swerved round corners.  When the crash occurred the car’s airbags were deployed but this did not prevent Ms Monaghan’s horric injuries. She had to be cut out of the car by firefighters and suffered numerous fractures to her face, head, body and limbs. “Kerrie Anne Monaghan is very lucky to be alive,” said fiscal Ms Bain. The court also heard of offences committed by Kirkbywhose address was given as Barlinnie Prison, on June . This time he was in a grey Ford Mondeo around .am when police spotted the car stationary on the A near the Pennyburn Roundabout. Kirkby was unsteady on his feet and slurring his speech, although a breath test proved negative. A a blood test found substances identied as cocaine and benzocaine. Defence lawyer Hugh Duncan said Kirkby’s relationship with Ms Monaghan was still ongoing. “He accepts full responsibility,” said the lawyer. “He comes across as remorseful to the injuries his partner suffered and to potential harm he could have done to others.” Mr Duncan said Kirkby had been remanded in custody since October , had undergone a detox programme, and had come to a realisation of his mental health issues. Sherf John Montgomery told Kirkby: “You drove dangerously at high speed for an extended period. I see no option but a custodial sentence.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnHMP BarlinnieVolvoAyrCourtsJusticeTroon

title: elliots prestwick evolve rebrand vics
story: NewsElliots in Prestwick to "evolve" with rebrand as Vics  The VineBosses at Buzzworks say the bar and restaurant must "evolve" as part of its transformation.ShareByStuart Wilson:,  FEB NewsBuzzworks managing director, Kenny Blair, is promising bold changes at Elliots "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailOne of Ayrshire’s biggest hospitality venues has closed for a “complete transformation”. Elliots in Prestwick will be given a new brand and feature live sport and entertainment seven days a week. The bar and restaurant shut its doors on Sunday, with bosses planning to reopen at Easter as Vic’s  The Vine. Buzzworks, who have operated Elliots as their flagship in the town, say the rebrand will be split into two halves. Managing director Kenny Blair said: “It’s essential to evolve within the hospitality industry and look at innovative ways to create new and exciting concepts for our customers. “Our work to reincarnate Elliots is part of our wider growth strategy, both benefiting the local community and Scotland’s hospitality industry.” Vic’s  The Vine will feature a -cover restaurant called The Vine serving food from breakfast until late. The bar will be called Vic’s and will be a “modern take on a traditional bar”, featuring sport and entertainment. Weekend opening hours will remain at .am.  Designer Jim Hamilton is leading the project, which will include a new glass roof in part of the bar. A new kitchen boasting a churrasco BBQ pit is also planned. Bosses say Vic’s will be the first venue in Ayrshire to serve fresh, unpasteurised tank beer straight from the brewery. Kenny added: “We’ve seen an appetite in the industry for more cool and modern pubs and, similarly to our T-Bar in Ayr, Vic’s will be a traditional bar with a twist. “This will both suit the local market and sit alongside our excellent new restaurant offering in Prestwick. “Our vision is to create the best day-to-night venue in Scotland and we are confident Vic’s  The Vine will match those expectations.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnAyrPrestwickAyr News

title: former royal hotel ayr sold
story: NewsFormer Royal Hotel in Ayr is sold at auctionBuilding is branded the most dangerous in the townShareByGary Fanning:,  FEB NewsRoyal Hotel Ayr"Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe former Royal Hotel, which has been described as the most dangerous building in Ayr, has been sold at auction. The iconic property, near Ayr Central, went under the hammer last Thursday. Wilsons Auctions Land and property sales executive, Lorren Mullen were managing the auction of the ex hotel. The three and a half storey building, which has lain empty for more than  years, consists of two commercial shop units on the ground floor and sandstone units above is located on Kyle Street. It had a guide price of pound,. A spokesman for Wilsons Auctions Land  Property Sales, said: “Unfortunately we cannot disclose any further detail on this property in terms of the identity of the purchaser or the sale price . “However this figure will be disclosed by the Registers of Scotland and the Ei Group in the coming months.” In May, the Post reported how plans to knock it down and turn it into a gym were rejected by councillors. Builders Dawn Developments wanted to build a new block in its place to home a gym and shops. But the plan was cut short as council planners want the hotel preserved or refurbished instead. And the sale happened after concerns about the safety of the former hotel were discussed at this month’s Fort, Seafield, and Wallacetown Community Council held at Ayr Town Hall. One community councillor said: “It is the most dangerous building in Ayr. ” It wasn’t the only empty building t discussed at the meeting. The meeting heard how young people were putting themselves in danger by gaining access to Belleisle House One said: ”If we can show concern then the council can take action and step in..” And the meeting was told how youngsters were “masquerading around” Strathdoon House. One member said: “If the fire service raise concerns then everyone has to take note of that.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnAyr

title: pet heaven crematorium opens doors
story: NewsPet Heaven crematorium opens doors in Ayr as businessman offers new serviceBusinessman Forbes Robertson is bidding to provide a new service for animal owners in South Ayrshire.ShareByStephen Houston:,  FEB NewsForbes at the helm of his newest business "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailWhen an adored pet pops off its mortal coil you used to allow the vet to handle it, or a space was found in the back garden. Now the proposition has got a whole lot dferent. Pet Heaven, a crematorium for family animals, has just opened in Ayr. And businessman Forbes Robertson believes it is the answer for many families who want to give their four legged - or two-legged in the case of birds - friends a splendid send-off. No expense has been spared in an -month project at the former commercial garage site in West Sanquhar Road. Area MP Bill Grant performed the official opening ceremony last week. The lavishly decorated gilded interior includes a parlour where families can pay their last respects. Entrepreneur Forbes, who has business interests throughout the area, revealed up to  people can attend the pet funeral services . Mourners can watch as their pet recedes behind the final curtain at the close of the service, similar to what would happen in a human ceremony at Masonhill. As yet Pet Heaven cannot handle horses, but the biggest of dogs to cats, hamsters and birds. There is a tea and coffee service as well as any choice of music desired and a book of remembrance in the reception area.  Much of the interior decoration has been gathered by Forbes, a keen antique hunter and auction room collector. The company will offer a collection service as well as provide a selection of remembrance urns for ashes. It seems no expense is spared by some dog lovers in the UK and recently a couple spent pound on a full funeral including a horse drawn glass hearse. Forbes said: “People sometimes care more about their animals than humans. “A farmer who contacted me askedhis dog goes before him, the animal would be cremated here and I will store the ashes. “He told me his lawyer would be in touch as he wanted buried with his dog. “Pets are loyal, they don’t steal from you and are there first thing in the morning and last thing at night.” MP Bill Grant said Pet Heaven was a signicant investment for the area. He said: “I am sure this will be welcomed by pet owners from all over the southwest, pet owners who have lost their best friend. “To have a dignied departure for that pet who has been their friend - in some cases for  years - is a great service. “The set-up Mr Robertson has here is wonderful and I think he can be proud of it. “That last journey for pets will be full of dignity and respect from Pet Heaven and its staff. “Indeed my family had a wee dog Blackie for  years and I don’t mind admitting, then a senior fire officer, that I cried unashamedly for an hour at the loss of our companion”.Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnAyrPetsSanquharAyr News

title: cold-weather-makes-it-harder-for-us-to-get-out-of-bed-says-survey
story: Chilly winter mornings lead usto spend an extra  hoursin bed over the colder months - just from hitting the snooze button.Weneed an extra  minutes in bed each morning during winter before wefeel brave enough to face the cold, according to a new survey.Of those surveyed who are currently employed,  per cent thought they were more likely to be late for work in the winter months because they found it harder to get up in the morning.Andof that %,the average worker will be late for work seven times in the course of an average winter because they overslept.One in five have been so cosy they have pulled a sickie to have a duvet day instead.A spokesperson for Andrews Heat for Hire, which commissioned the study, said: ldquoDarker, colder mornings can make waking up in winter months more challenging than any other time of the year.ldquoAnd while an additional quarter of an hour snoozing each day doesnrsquot seem like a big sacrice, over the course of the winter we lose an entire day to those few extra minutes in bed.Regionally, Scots are the quickest to get up and face the day when the weather turns, spending  minutes extra in bed, while those living in Yorkshire are fondest of their covers, resisting the cold until theyrsquove had  extra minutes dozing.One in two Brits find it harder to get themselves out of bed in winter more than any other time of year, and a third think they are more likely to hit the snooze button when the mornings are dark and cold.And seven in  said a few more minutes with their duvet is too tempting when the weather outside looks chilly.To read the full results of the study, visitandrews-sykes blog.Three in five of those questioned make it tougher to leave their beds by taking actions to make their set-up as warm and comfortable as possible.Of these,  per cent will buy a thicker duvet when the weather begins to turn, and  per cent will put an extra blanket on the bed to keep the cold away.More than seven in  even have the foresight to set their heating to come on before they wake up so their home is warm when they wake, clicking on  minutes before they stir.One in five of those surveyed have been so attached to their bedspread they have been late for a meet-up with friends or loved ones - and will also cancel six gatherings entirely over a typical winter because its too cold.Nearly one in two Brits are unable to shake their hibernation instincts when the temperature plummets and spend more time in bed during the winter than any other time of year.Three in  find themselves going to bed earlier as the evenings draw in sooner, and one in eight set their morning alarms later than they usually would to grab a few extra minutes before feeling the chill.A spokesperson for Andrews Heat for Hire, who comissioned the survey, said: ldquoWith a cold snap predicted over the coming weeks,duvets are only going to become even more inviting. At least Brits are taking measures to reduce the struggle, by planning ahead and setting their heating to come on before their alarm.

title: channel-4-show-hunted-is-looking-for-borders-contestants

title: confused-commuters-have-world-turned-upside-down-in-galashiels
story: COMMUTERS had their world turned upside down in Galashiels last week.For four or five days confused bus passengers at the Transport Interchange struggled to read the real-time arrival and departure screens - as they were all upside down.And the confusion continued right through to the start of this week.Selkirk pensioner Jaye Riddell told us: "It was a bit dficult to make out when buses were due - I cant read upside down writing."There was one child lying on the ground trying to read the times out to to his grandparents."Thankfully the train timetables were the right way up."Scottish Borders Council is responsible for the large interactive timetable screens at the Transport Interchange.And their IT people managed to fix the upside-down problem on Monday.A spokesman told us: "The issue with the information boards has been resolved and everything is the right way up now."

title: ben-magowan-announced-as-melrosian-elect-for-2019
story: TAKING up the reins as this years Melrosian-Elect is a -year-old childrens nurse from Gattonside.Ben Magowan was announced in the role at the annual Ex-Melrosians Association Burns Supper on Saturday night.The former pupil of Melrose Primary, St Marys School and Earlston High said: "I was very nervous on the evening but its such an honour to be asked to be the Melrosian-Elect."It was an exciting evening and I had my family there to support me."Im already looking forward to the summer and have started learning about the other towns festivals."The Burns Supper was a sell-out and guests were entertained by Sandy Telfer who proposed the toast to the Immortal Memory followed by Harry Fletchers Toast to the Lassies and Annabel Crawfords reply. The toast to Town and Trade was proposed by Mark Robertson with Ex-Melrosian David Crawford replying. Russell Mackay proposed the vote of thanks to Michael Crawford for his rendition of Address to a Haggis, entertainers Drew Scott and Donald Swanson as well as special guest Jim Hutchison for performing Tam o Shanter. Thanks were also extended to the catering and bar staff at Melrose RFC.This years week-long Melrose Festival, which celebrates the history of the town, will take place June  until June  .The Rideout is on the June  and the Crowning of the Festival Queen is on Thursday, June .The Queen and Court for the festival will be appointed in May.

title: devon-based-hotel-group-buys-cringletie-house
story: AN award-winning country house hotel in Peeblesshire is about to change hands.Cringletie House Hotel, which was named AA Hotel of the Year for Scotland in , was placed on the market just over a year ago with an asking price of pound. million.The -bespoke-bedroom baronial retreat has been bought by Devon-based Cross Hotels Limited.And the official hand over will take place on February .Johanna and Jacob van Houdt have owned Cringletie for the past  years.Jacob told us: ldquoWe acquired Cringletie in a derelict state in  and invested time and money creating a destination for holidays in the Scottish Borders."Cringletie is now ready for a new phase of development and further growth."We are delighted that the Crossrsquos are bringing new energy and ideas to this magnicent project.Cringletie is set in  acres of land near Eddleston.As well as offering guests luxury room accommodation there is also a two-bedroom letting cottage in the grounds as well as staff accommodation.The hotel is also home to a -year-old walled garden and Dutch styled parterre garden.And there is also a large area of land available for further development.Bill Cross, Director of Cross Hotels, said: ldquoThe van Houdtrsquos have created a very stylish hotel at Cringletie House."We look forward to enhancing the operation and in due course extending the facilities."

title: mens-shed-goes-all-pc-with-eildon-donation
story: LOCAL social landlord Eildon Housing are setting a recycling example by donating old PCs and office furniture to a Mens Shed group.The Selkirk-based housing association handed over four computers as well as cupboards to Kelso Mens Shed last week.Eildons Chief Executive Nile Istephan told us: "As part of the on-going modernisation of our business processes, we had some surplus furniture and computers that we wanted to put to good use."In line with one of our corporate values of being connected to the communities that we work within, it is great that we can donate our surplus equipment to such a worthy cause.ldquoThe Menrsquos Shed movement provides the community with a very valuable service, by offering recreational facilities to help advance the social needs, health and well-being of people of all ages and backgrounds living in Kelso and surrounding areas."Along with a number of other organisations we have also provided financial support for a Menrsquos Shed Development worker to maximise the potential for this inspirational idea across our region.Kelso Mens Shed already has over  members.The organisation meets every Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday between am and pm.Bob Stather from Kelso Menrsquos Shed added: ldquoWe are extremely grateful for this very kind donation which will be of enormous benefit to our new Shedders."Getting on-line will be a priority for some of our new members, and this will be made possible thanks to Eildonrsquos generous donation.

title: selkirk-woman-accused-of-embezzling-16k-from-mother-in-law
story: A SELKIRK woman has been accused of embezzlement at the towns sherf court.Kirsten Darling is alleged to have embezzled the sum of pound,.The -year-old is said to have been granted welfare and financial Power of Attorney along withher husband on behalf of her mother-in-law who was then suffering from dementia.The offence is said to have happened at her home in Leslie Place, between April and July last year.Thecase was continued without plea until February .

title: innerleithen-shoplifter-admits-trolley-dash-at-asda
story: AN INNERLEITHEN man stole groceries to the value of pound. from the ASDA superstore in Galashiels and then ran off after being confronted by a staff member.Peter Dawes, , of Craig Terrace, pleaded guilty at Selkirk Sherf Court to the offence which happened on December .Procurator fiscal Graham Fraser explained how Dawes was challenged over a trolley of groceries after leaving the store and was asked what check-out he had paid for them at.He said: "He was asked to come back into the store and he bent down to tie his shoe lace and then ran off."Dawes then drove off from the car park but was traced by police because he was registered keeper of the vehicle.Mr Fraser added: "There was no success in the theft as there was a full recovery of the goods but it was a substantial amount he would have got away with."Defence lawyer Mat Patrick said: "He does not have any explanation why he has done this."He has no excuse for it."It was not a very sophisticated attempt of theft."Mr Patrick said his client had pleaded guilty at the first opportunity and there was a full recovery.Dawes was fined pound.

title: single-borderers-can-now-apply-to-appear-on-first-dates-hotel
story: MATCHMAKING managerFred Sirieix and the First Dates team are taking reservations at the First Dates Hotel for a new summer season of love in .The popular Channel  TV show sees the well-known maicirctre d take a break from the shows restaurant to take over the running of a luxury hotel abroad where he will welcome singletons from the UK on a two-day dating stay.Last year the show was filmed in Campania near Naples in Italy.Producers from the show help you find a partner from a pool of other singletons and captures the highs and lows of your first date on camera.At the end of the meal, couples will choose to split the bill, go home alone or spend the next day with your date at the hotels location which is yet to be revealed for this years series.A producer added: "Wersquore looking for singletons from across the UK to join us in Italy for a dose of La Dolce Vita as we match you on the most romantic date of your le."Each episode will feature a number of intimate first dates. In-depth interviews will help the viewers get to know the daters."Discreet cameras will record the date from start to finish - from first impressions, through all the awkward, heart-warming and funny moments, to the end of the date and the discussion about whether or not a second date is on the cards."If yoursquore single and looking for love apply now."Your application will be received by a member of the production team at Twenty Twenty.To fill out the application form, visit:http:www.twentytwenty.tv casting first-dates_.aspx

title: violent-galashiels-teenager-sentenced-to-unpaid-work
story: A GALASHIELS teenager who admitted a series of violence offences has been ordered to carry out  hours of unpaid work at Selkirk Sherf Court.Dario Durante, , pleaded guilty to punching a male repeatedly on the head in Church Square, Galashiels, on June .He also admitted behaving in a threatening or abusive manner in the back of a police vehicle in Croft Street, Galashiels, and kicking parked vehicles and also bins in his home street on September .Durante also admitted kicking a female police officer on the leg at Tesco and struggling violently with other officers.

title: newsagents-ban-for-alleged-shoplifter
story: A -year-old woman appeared from custody at Selkirk Sherf Court accused behaving in a threatening or abusive manner and theft by shoplting.Elizabeth McLean of Lothian Road, pleaded not guilty and a trial date was fixed for Jedburgh Sherf Court on April .She was released on bail with the special conditions not to enter RS McColl in Canoingate, Jedburgh, and not to contact three named females.

title: flytippers-carpeted-for-desecrating-pipers-grave
story: FLY-TIPPERS have desecrated the grave of a legendary th century piper from Peebles who met his tragic end after taking off on foot to play the pipes from Traquair to Edinburgh Castle.Locals have blasted inconsiderate dumpers who left rolled up carpets and tiles on the B granites road between Innerleithen and Gorebridge.One of the sites affected was the burial place of the itinerant piper who was known to frequent the local hostelries taking wagers that he could play any tune that a customer named.The tale goes that he played his final tune one drunken evening after taking a bet that he couldnt play non-stop on all the way to Edinburgh Castle.It is said that one of the crowd resorted to sabotage and cut a hole in the windbag of the pipes. The steep climb and extra effort required to play exhausted the piper who sat down never to rise again.It was at this very spot, midway between Innerleithen and Heriot that the piper was laid to rest.Disgusted by what he discovered on the roadside, local resident Nick Tokely said: ldquoOne of the five spots to have stuff dumped was the piperrsquos grave which is a scenic landmark. This time it was industrial amounts of carpet and carpet tiles, but its dferent items each week.

title: lottery-cash-to-expand-td1-youth-drop-ins
story: A GALASHIELS youth charity has been boosted with a windfall from the Scottish Childrens Lottery.TD Youth Hub has been awarded a pound, grant from the fund.TD Youth Hub supports young people in and around Galashiels by offering evening drop-ins, streetwork, young parents group, music projects, mentoring and physical activities.The Scottish Childrens Lottery cash will enable the charity to expand its drop-in service, which provides young people with a safe place to meet friends, speak to youth workers and relax.Douglas Ormston, TD Youth Hub Manager, said: "This grant from the Scottish Childrens Lottery is so important to our organisation."Our drop-ins provide us with opportunities to engage with young people, find out what their needs are and then plan projects and services which suit them, giving young people opportunities to shape their own positive futures.The Scottish Childrens Lottery was launched in October  to raise money for children in Scotland, with proceeds helping to improve the lives of children right across the country and make a real dference to those who need it most.Trustee Kirsteen Campbell said: ldquoI am delighted that we are able to provide funding for TD Youth Hub from the money generated from the Scottish Childrenrsquos Lottery, which was established in order to promote and support the development and potential of children and young people in Scotland."Thank you to those who play the Scottish Childrenrsquos Lottery - you are helping to support the great work that our charities undertake.

title: stobo-goes-third-generation-as-md-steps-down
story: IT is one of the most successful businesses in Peeblesshire.And after  years at the helm of Stobo Castle Health Spa, Stephen Winyard is handing over control to his two sons.The Winyard family bought the th century castle in the early s.Stephens parents Robert and Gaynor undertook a major makeover of the run-down castle - opening it as one of the countrys first health farms in .And a decade later Stephen took on the running of the business.At the height of srsquo fashion, it featured just  bedrooms with shared avocado bathroom suites, medical checks for guests and calorie-controlled meals.Since then, signicant investment has taken place and a poundmilion state-of-the-art spa extension in  led to the creation of  treatment rooms, a fully-equipped gym, saunas, steam rooms, a stunning -metre ozone-treated infinity pool and outdoor hot tubs.Guests are often found sipping bubbly between rejuvenating spa and beauty treatments, exploring the outdoor Japanese water garden or dining in the wood-led dining room.The addition of the stunning Cashmere Suite complete with cashmere lined walls and original works of Scottish art, cashmere-covered hand-made Italian beds and an opulent bathroom with its famed pound, hand-carved bath for a single piece of limestone, has proved another lure. It is widely acknowledged as the most opulent guest suite in the land.More recently, the new Ladies Restroom made the headlines as Scotlandrsquos most luxurious loos.Last year Stobo recorded a pre-tax profit of over pound million.And with planned future investment, the luxury spa resort is forecast to go from strength-to-strength.Last week Mr Winyard officially announced that he will step aside from his managing director role to become chairman of the business.But Stobo Castle will remain firmly in family hands with his son Elliot becoming managing director and other son Mitchell taking on the position of projects director.Stephenrsquos we Mandy will continue in her role as a director of the company.Stephen told us: ldquoStobo Castlersquos evolution from what was basically a derelict property, has been remarkable."My mother was chairman of the Society of Health and Beauty Therapists at the time. She had a vision that it could become a health farm, at a time when such places were virtually unheard of."Today Stobo Castle is Scotlandrsquos only destination spa and one of many peoplersquos lsquomust visitrsquo places to relax and rejuvenate."Sadly, my parents are no longer alive to see it, however its success is testimony to their incredible vision and hard work."Stobo Castlersquos staff have also contributed immensely to its success, many of whom have been here almost since the beginning.

title: scottish-borders-council-in-line-for-more-cash
story: SCOTTISH Borders Council could be in for a larger settlement grant than first expected following a deal between rival parties in Holyrood.A new funding settlement for local authorities has been agreed in the Scottish parliament following a last-minute deal between the majority Scottish National Party and minority Greens ahead of a vote on the annual budget.The deal includes more core funding for councils and extra powers for them to levy local parking and tourist taxes.Derek MacKay, the Scottish Governmentrsquos finance secretary, first unveiled proposals for the budget in December , including added funding for schools and the National Health Service, as well as increasing income tax for those earning pound, or more.Opposition parties moved to block the bid, partly due to the SNP refusing to rule out calling another independence referendum and also because they say the budget would result in a poundm funding cut for local authorities.However, the deal with the Scottish Greens means the budget is now likely to be passed.Scottish Borders Council leader Shona Haslam said: ldquoThis settlement does go some way to mitigating the cuts that we were expecting. However, it has a narrow focus in terms of local taxation.ldquoGiven the consultation only concluded last Friday, it is surprising that the Scottish Government were able to announce the tourist tax today.The new deal with the Scottish Greens includes an extra poundm for the core local government settlement, a move to three-year local authority budgets and legislation that will give councils control over tourism taxes.The deal also includes raising the council tax cap, meaning local authorities will now be able to increase council tax by .%, up from %.Fellow Tweeddale East councillor Stuart Bell, also leader of the councilrsquos Scottish national party opposition group , said: ldquoSignicant announcements have been made on a phased development of alternatives to the council tax. ldquoAlthough I donrsquot advocate that locally we should immediately take advantage of the proposal to give local authorities power to introduce a tourist tax, or the suggested workplace parking levy, these are adjustments that some Scottish city authorities will want to take up after the necessary legislation is approved.ldquoI am also pleased that talks on meaningful alternatives to council tax will restart and that with a three-year funding settlement, as opposed to the current one-year deals, there will be more clarity for local authorities on future funding.ldquoThere are also small changes in the - revenue grants for local authorities. Despite the constant chant of despair from the Bordersrsquo Tories, I said all along that the December announcements of funding for the council were only provisional. ldquoThe Conservatives who lead the council like to highlight that we were told we might see pound.m less for core revenue funding next year, conveniently forgetting to talk about promised money for new services such as the massive expansion in early learning and childcare.ldquoThey also omit to tell Borderers that we are getting poundm more next year as capital funding, almost exactly offsetting the change in revenue funding.ldquoWe must wait until the detail of the poundm package from the Scottish Government is analysed by officers, but my provisional calculation is that the new funding announcements could give the council more than pound.m, meaning that we will see a clear cash increase in next yearrsquos funding for core revenue and capital.ldquoSadly, we are being told that the Conservatives in Holyrood may vote against these welcome changes.Rachael Hamilton, Conservative MSP for Ettrick, Roxburgh and Berwickshire, said: ldquoThanks to the SNP, Scots across the country are about to be hit by a triple tax bombshell.ldquoThis budget not only taxes aspiration but taxes people for driving to work, which is quite frankly ridiculous in a constituency like mine, where travelling by car is essential.ldquoWe will pay the highest income taxes in the UK, council tax could go up and now you might even be taxed hundreds of pounds a year for taking your car to work.ldquoThe SNP have run out of ideas on how to grow and expand the economy. Instead, they have decided to raid the pockets of hard-working families.,params: .pushMr Bell added: ldquoMy big message to the Borders Tories is to drop their mentality of dependence and to take responsibility for balancing a Borders budget. ldquoThe power to make change is in the hands of the council and they should stop trying to shirk local responsibility. Power to finance - expenditure is in the hands of the administration.ldquoDerek MacKay has announced that more could be raised from further increasing the local council tax to a new upper level of over %, as the Scottish Government has lted the previous cap.ldquoFurther, the Tory-led Borders administration should take responsibility for properly managing our councilrsquos affairs. ldquoFigures I have seen show that there are unrealised savings of over pound.m that were planned in last yearrsquos budget which have not been realised in practice.ldquoIf these saving had been made, then there would be less cuts this year. If we hadnrsquot poured it away in unrealised savings and could add this new money, perhaps the Bordersrsquo revenue finances would balance. ldquoWhat is the point in giving the administration any more moneythey canrsquot properly manage what we now get. They must stop blaming everyone  and put their own affairs in order.What do you think Send us your views for our letters page, including your name and address, here

title: scottish-borders-council-food-crackdown
story: A CRACKDOWN on the sale of unhealthy foods could soon be served up by Scottish Borders Council.Trading standards officers could take on a larger role policing the selling and marketing of high-fat, high-sugar and high-salt foods.In July , the Scottish Government produced a consultation paper setting out the foods they felt needed to be targeted in order to reduce the calorie intake and weight of Scots.These include confectionery, sweet biscuits, crisps, savoury snacks, cakes, pastries, puddings and soft drinks with added sugar.The consultation askslocal authorities agree with this list and whether more items should be added.The councilrsquos consultation response, drafted by Keith Allan of NHS Borders, states that the authority believes ice-cream, ready meals and dairy desserts should also be included in the crackdown, explaining: ldquoWhile it will certainly be useful to target the discretionary foods listed above, there is also a need to include drinks high in sugar, salt, fat or calories irrespective of whether or not this is added.ldquoSimilarly, ice-cream and dairy desserts should also come under the scope of the new policy as they are often high in fat and high in sugar and do not form an essential dietary component.ldquoWhile dairy-based desserts could offer some benefits in terms of calcium and other nutrients, these would be available from other sources in a healthy diet.ldquoTheir benefit in a dairy-based dessert would be offset by the high-energy density and presence of salts, sugars and fats.At a full meeting of the council last Thursday, members voted in favour of approving the officerrsquos draft response despite ided opinion amongst councillors.East Berwickshire councillor Helen Laing , a health worker, was strongly in favour of the consultation response, saying: ldquoI have worked in the adult health service my entire adult le.ldquoAnd I have seen first hand the impact on peoplersquos wellbeing of poor diet and the suffering it causes. In my current role, there is barely a day that goes by without discussing with a parent or carer the impact of sugar in their childrenrsquos food, but, letrsquos face it, fat, salt and sugar make things taste nice, and itrsquos easy to fall into the trap of overindulgence.ldquoThatrsquos okay every now and again, but regular overindulgence of fat, sugar and salt leads to grave consequences, such as tooth decay, heart disease, diabetes and cancer.ldquoObesity, including childhood obesity, is fast becoming the epidemic of our age.ldquoMany of us are blissfully unaware just how much salt, sugar and fat is in the foods we buy.ldquoBig companies which produce, promote and retail these products are in it to maximise profits.ldquoThey have at their disposal expensive advertising and marketing which hugely influence our choices and purchasing habits.However, Galashiels councillor Harry Scottfelt the proposals amounted to unwelcome government meddling with personal choice, saying: ldquoIrsquom not in agreement with any of the proposals in this paper.,params: .pushldquoI appreciate the problem, but this is typical nanny state, dictating to us how we should live our lives.ldquoIt will cause unnecessary restrictions on business, specialist retailers will find it hard to market themselves, and I doubt very much whether it will have any impact on the groups it is targeting.ldquoWhilst Irsquom very much in favour of labelling food to make clearer to the consumers whatrsquos in it, in principle I am against compulsion.ldquoPeople have to take responsibility for their own lives and lestyle choices, and as long as you keep within the law, the state should have no place in telling you what you can eat or drink.A motion put forward by Councillor Scott called for the response to be completely rejected, but it was not supported by his fellow councillors.Instead, they opted to vote to submit the consultation response in full, albeit as a council officer response not as a political response.According to NHS Health Scotland, in ,  per cent of Scotlandrsquos children were at risk of becoming overweight and  per cent were at risk of becoming obese.That same year,  per cent of adults were overweight, almost half of them being classed as obese.The NHS says that some of the health risks of being overweight include an increased chance of developing type-two diabetes and a greater risk of heart disease, stroke and some cancers.What do you think Send us your views for our letters page, including your name and address, here

title: pothole-plea-to-boost-borders-cycle-tourism
story: A SCOTTISH Borders councillor has been taking the council to task over the state of the regionrsquos roads, raising fears it could impact on the regionrsquos cycling tourism economy.Galashiels and District councillor Harry Scott has raised issues with the council about the state of the B Heriot to Innerleithen road, designated as a cycling route but, he says, in ldquoa state of serious disrepair.At a meeting of Scottish Borders Council on Thursday  January, councillor Scott asked for the road to be resurfaced: ldquoThe B Heriot to Innerleithen road is listed as an official Borders cycle route with the aim ofattracting touring cyclists to enjoy the scenery and spend money in the Borders.ldquoSeveral sections of the road, particularly towards Innerleithen are presently in a state of serious disrepair, and hazardous not only for cars, but particularly for cyclists.ldquoMay I ask that at the least the most hazardous sections of the B be considered for inclusion as a matter of priority in the roads departmentrsquos scheme of works and overlays for the year  .In response, Selkirkshire councillor Gordon Edgar, the councilrsquos executive member for roads and infrastructure, told the chamber: ldquoThe road is inspected every two months in accordance with the councilrsquos policy and standards guidelines.ldquoAny defects noted during these inspections are recorded and instructions are issued to carry out reactive maintenance as required within the timescale guidelines.ldquoMaintenance of the councilrsquos adopted road network is programmed by our asset team.ldquoSome sections of the B road are listed as lsquobeing considered for possible inclusionrsquo in future surface treatment programmes.ldquoUnfortunately, the overall condition of our roads network means that we are not in a position to agree to treat all identied sections with a permanent form of treatment and must apply a prioritisation process to determine an annual programme which means our annual budget.In a prepared statement, councillor Scott said: ldquoMy reasons are that we are selling the Scottish Borders to tourists, cycling being one of the strands.ldquoThe B leads from the Edinburgh and Lothians area to the heart of Borders cycling in the Innerleithen and Peebles areas.ldquoLike any tourists we hope that they will extend their stay and their exploration of the Borders from that base.ldquoThe B is no better or worse than many of our other roads, and Irsquom not looking for a quick fixes because in the current financial climate, there are none.ldquoIrsquom simply asking that the road is not forgotten in the work schedule, and that at the least the worst sections can be identied for improvement or repair.What do you think Send us your views for our title: business-brunch-whets-appetite-for-languages
story: YOUNG people from four Borders schools have taken part in a business and languages event.S and S students from Earlston High, Jedburgh Grammar, Kelso High and Peebles High joined  learners from across the Edinburgh, Lothians and Borders areas for the Business Brunch in Edinburghs Dynamic Earth.The event on January  demonstrated the relevance of language skills in a work context and aimed to encourage pupils to continue with their language studies into the senior phase of their secondary education and beyond.Pupils heard from a range of business leaders who view language skills as key to the growth and success of their company.A teacher attending the event said: ldquoTodayrsquos event has opened my learnersrsquo eyes to languages as a key skill for work in all industries, and as something to enrich their lives.One of the young people added to this, and commented: ldquoI learnt that languages are useful for everything, including my personal le. I also discovered that knowing a language makes you a lot more employable. I didnt expect places like Dynamic Earth to have languages as one of their work experience opportunities.Lynn Houmdi from Maroc-o-phile and one of the speakers, stated: ldquoThe event was really well-organised. I chatted to people on a few of the stands and was really impressed that so many companies and organisations are actively seeking language skills.Sophie Dawes, Project Officer at Developing the Young WorkforceEdinburgh, Midlothian and East Lothian regional group, and one of the organisers, stated: ldquoGiving young people an opportunity to hear directly from businesses across a broad range of sectors highlighted why continuing with languages at school could be so beneficial to opening up a world of opportunities beyond school. With a iety of industry led workshops and exhibitors speaking directly with young people, everyone had opportunities to be informed and inspired."The day was action packed from start to finish and the feedback received from young people and teachers has been so positive. Wersquore already looking forward to planning for !The event was organised by SCILT, Scotlandrsquos National Centre for Languages based at University of Strathclyde, in partnership with Developing the Young WorkforceEdinburgh, Midlothian, East Lothian, West Lothian and Borders regional groups together with the University Council for Modern Languages Scotland .Fhiona Mackay, Director of SCILT said: ldquoIn these times of uncertainty, it is even more important than ever that we equip our young people with the skills they will need for le beyond school. We want them to be outward-looking and able to operate in an interdependent world. Events such as these highlight the importance of language skills and intercultural competencies in the world of work.ldquoThe business leaders who speak at these events give of their own time because they understand how much these skills are needed and valued by employers and how vital they are for Scotlandrsquos business community. This kind of collaboration is an example of how education and business sectors can work together for their mutual benefit so that we can support young people and help them develop the portfolio of skills that employers require in their workforce.

title: msp-urges-borders-women-to-have-smear-tests
story: A REGIONAL MSP is encouraging women in the Borders to attend regular smear tests.Claudia Beamishhas joined charity Jorsquos Cervical Cancer Trustrsquos campaign to get more people going to screenings more often.She told us: ldquoLast year cervical screening uptake in Scotland fell from . per cent to . per cent which means more than one in four eligible women missed their screen test.ldquoYet regular screening prevents up to  per cent of cervical cancers developing.ldquoThe statistics are particularly worrying for younger women where uptake is only  per cent despite the fact cervical cancer is the most common cancer for women aged under .ldquoI know going for a smear test isnrsquot easy, it can be uncomfortable and awkward but it is so important to attend appointments and I urge people not to put them off. title: young-borderers-invited-to-compete-in-art-competition
story: BUDDING young artists from the Scottish Borders have until March  to enter the fth annual John Byrne National Drawing Competition.The competition is sponsored by renowned artist and playwright, John Byrne, in partnership with Education Scotland.It aims to get pupils from P to S to channel their imagination and creativity into drawings.Last yearrsquos competition saw around  drawings submitted from schools across Scotland.John Byrne said: ldquoThis is a great way to give young people from the Scottish Borders the opportunity to harness their artistic skills and love for drawing.ldquoIrsquom hoping to see even more Scottish Borders pupils unveiling their creative talents this year.Alan Armstrong, Strategic Director for Education Scotland said: ldquoArt and design is an important part of the curriculum and this competition aims to encourage pupils across Scotland to develop their drawing skills and use their creativity.ldquoEducation Scotland is proud to be hosting this competition with John and our education partners as it is a great way to raise the profile of drawing.Entries into the competition can be of any size and created in any media, but they must be lsquodrawingsrsquo. There is no theme.Three winners and  runners-up will have their drawings included in an exhibition at The Tannahill Centre in Paisley which will run from March  for six weeks.Winners will receive a limited edition print by John, a voucher for art materials and a book token. story: A CANADIAN folk-roots duo is stopping off in the Borders as part of a UK tour.Gordie Tentrees and Jaxon Haldane have announced eight Scottish dates as part of a national tour including stops in Biggar, Kelso and Coldingham.Since coming together in , Gordie and Jaxon have performed concerts in  countries, including Celtic Connections in Glasgow. title: melrose-farmer-drove-digger-at-university-professor-neighbour
story: A Melrose farmer drove an agricultural digger at a university professor in a neighbourly dispute, Selkirk Sherf Court has been told.James Morton was then involved in a violent struggle with police officers in a cow shed which ended upwith them falling into an animal waste pit.Details of the bizarre bust-up emerged last week when the -year-old was fined pound after admitting a charge of threatening or abusive behaviour.Graham Fraser, prosecuting, explained how there had been a long standing neighbourly dispute between the farm atKaeside, near Melrose,and the home of Dr. Britta Kalkreuter who is an professor at the School of Textiles and Design at Heriot Watt University, and her husband.At lunchtime on November  she heard a banging noise outside her home and walked down the access road with an Ipad for filming purposes to investigate.Mr Fraser explained how Morton was in a JCB with a bucket in front digging up earth and on seeing his neighbour drove at a steady speed towards her.He added:"It stopped so close to her she could physically touch the vehicle."The police were contacted but Morton would not speak to the officers when they arrived.Police officers viewed the video footage on the Ipad and took the view it was a "deliberate attempt to intimidate" the neighbour.Mr Fraser said Morton then ran off into the cow shed and was involved in a violent struggle with the officers which resulted in them falling into animal waste stored in the shed.He continued: "During the course of the struggle a set of keys came away from a constable as well as a warrant card.The keys were never found."After being cautioned and charged Morton insisted Ms Kalkreuter should have moved out of the way of the digger.Defence lawyer Mat Patrick said his client should be given a degree of sympathy as he had been engaging with the Scottish Environmental Protection Agency and had spent thousands of pounds trying to recty drainage problems in the area.He explained that Ms Kaulkreuter and her husband had reported the farm to SEPA on three occasions and theScottish SPCA four times.Mr Patrick added:"It has been going on for some time and he was at the end of his tether. He felt it was a vendetta when he saw her holding the Ipad and that it was being done to provoke him. Unfortunately he has bitten and lost the rag.He has accepted that."He explained that the incident with the police arose because Morton had panicked.Mr Patrick concluded:"He just wishes he and his neighbour could stay apart and there are legal ways to avoid this.It is a situation which needs to cool down."Morton, who has a previous conviction, had a fine of pound imposed by Sherf Adrian Cotham reduced to pound due to the guilty plea.

title: pupils-to-move-school-following-contaminated-water-find
story: ASSURANCES have been given to parents after high levels of lead were found in a school water supply.Education chiefs have also handed out bottled water to pupils at Ednam Primary School in Kelso.The high levels of lead were discovered in taps at four wash basins during routine water testing last Thursday.An immediate ban on drinking or using tap water was implemented.And alternative catering arrangements were introduced.Scottish Borders Council Chief Executive Tracey Logan told the Border : ldquoThe action taken by the council is very much precautionary but it was felt important to immediately act in order to reduce any potential risks to pupils and staff."As well as members of staff Ednam Primary School has a roll of  pupils and nine nursery children.Following mid-term holidays later this month all pupils and staff will move to nearby Broomlands Primary to allow further detailed investigations and required repair works to take place.Ms Logan added: ldquoWe are currently finalising arrangements for the move to Broomlands and we aim to ensure disruption is minimised as much as possible."We will also be keeping parents fully updated throughout this process."Health chiefs dont believe there are any serious risks to pupils and staff.Tim Patterson, Joint Director of Public Health for SBC and NHS Borders, said: ldquoWhile the risk to public health is low, all parents and others affected have been provided with public health information to help answer any health-related queries they have.ldquoIf any parents or staff have any signicant health concerns, they are advised to contact their GP in the usual manner.

title: football-club-vandals-leave-trail-of-sectarian-slurs
story: AN anti-sectarian charity has voiced its anger and concern after a vandalism attack at a local football club.Vile anti-Catholic slogans were painted onto doors, signs and windows at Vale of Leithens Victoria Park ground.And more than a dozen pro-Rangers phrases were also daubed onto the enclosure and dug-outs.It is estimated the clean-up will run into several hundred pounds.But its the repulsive sectarian slogans which have caused the most anger with some.Dave Scott, director of Nil By Mouth, tours the country educating schoolchildren about the isiveness and dangers of sectarian behaviour.And he finds it hard to believe that it is happening on his doorstep.Dave told us: "This is utterly moronic behaviour and you wouldnrsquot need two hands to count the IQ points of those behind it."As a Gala Fairydean Rovers fan Irsquove been to Victoria Park on numerous occasions and know how hard the clubrsquos committee and volunteers work to keep the Vale going and the last thing they need is having to clean up after mindless acts of vandalism."Sectarianism in the Borders is rare with minimal convictions when compared to other parts of the country.And Nil By Mouth hope this attack in Innerleithen will be a isolated incident.Mr Scott added: "As part of our Kiss Bigotry Goodbye campaign we will contact the club and offer to sponsor a game in the very near future to show that true football supporters love the game and hate this sort of nonsense."Vale of Leithens committee have already forked out thousands of pounds to bring their ground up to Lowland League standards.And they regularly have to carry out clean-ups and repairs following minor vandalism.But chairman Stuart Robertson admits this is the worst attack hes witnessed.Mr Robertson said: "This is the worst case of vandalism Ive seen in all my years of being involved at the Vale."There is paint everywhere and we are going to have to clean it off the best we can before our next game."People work so hard at Vale of Leithen yet you get people who come along and undo all the good work."Police Scotland confirmed an investigation has been launched.A spokesperson said: "Police in the Borders are investigating following a report of vandalism at a football club in Innerleithen."The incident took place between am on Friday, February  and am on Monday, February  in the Victoria Park area."Inquiries are ongoing and anyone who witnessed any suspicious behaviour in the area over the weekend of February  and , or has information that can help identy those involved, is asked to contact officers on  and quote incident number  of February ."Alternatively a report can be made to Crimestoppers anonymously on   ."

title: pm-to-meet-main-ni-parties-as-she-engages-on-backstop
story: The Prime Minister will meet the main Northern Irish parties later as she steps up her bid for a breakthrough on the backstop.Theresa May has already had conversations with business and community leaders during her two-day trip to Belfast.She is expected to meet the Democratic Unionists and Sinn Fein among others on Wednesday.The premier has suggested that she is seeking ldquochanges to the controversial backstop in her Brexit deal, rather than its total removal from the UKrsquos EU Withdrawal Agreement.In a speech in Belfast, the Prime Minister restated her ldquounshakeable commitment to avoiding a hard border in Ireland after Brexit, pledging: ldquoThe UK Government will not let that happen. I will not let that happen.The Prime Minister is expected to meet the Democratic Unionists and Sinn Fein among others on Wednesday during Stormont talks .But asked how she could convince the people of Northern Ireland to accept a Brexit deal which was stripped of the backstop, Mrs May said:ldquoIrsquom not proposing to persuade people to accept a deal that doesnrsquot contain that insurance policy for the future.ldquoWhat Parliament has said is that they believe there should be changes made to the backstop.It was in that light that she was working with MPs, the Irish government and the EU to find a way to meet the commitment to take Britain out of the EU on March  with a deal which avoided a hard Irish border, she said.The Irish Government accused the Prime Minister of harbouring unrealistic expectations over the backstop.The mechanism has polarised nationalists and unionists.Many unionists believe the ldquoinsurance policy to preserve a frictionless frontier on the island of Ireland could threaten the integrity of the UKNorthern Irelandrsquos customs regulations ied from Great Britain after Brexit.Nationalists and many business leaders fear major disruption to trade and a hard border threatening peace process gainsno deal is struck and the backstop is not triggered.Meanwhile, Irish Taoiseach Leo Varadkar will travel to Brussels for meetings with European Council president Donald Tusk and European Commission president Jean-Claude Juncker.Mrs May is due to visit the Belgian capital on Thursday, where she will hold a series of talks with key figures including Mr Tusk, Mr Juncker, European Parliament president Antonio Tajani and the European Parliamentrsquos chief Brexit negotiator Guy Verhofstadt.It will be the Prime Ministerrsquos first chance to hold first face-to-face talks in Brussels since the Withdrawal Agreement reached last November was rejected by the House of Commons.And it comes a week after MPs voted for an amendment tabled by Conservative grandee Sir Graham Brady and backed by the Prime Minister which ldquorequires the Northern Ireland backstop to be replaced with alternative arrangements to avoid a hard border.Mrs May will seek to secure changes which can persuade MPs to support her deal in a series of votes expected on February .In Westminster, the working group bringing together senior Eurosceptic and former Remain-supporting Tories will continue efforts to agree alternatives to the backstop along the lines of the Malthouse Compromise.Talks involving Conservatives including Brexiteers Iain Duncan Smith, Theresa Villiers, Steve Baker and Owen Paterson along with former Remainers Nicky Morgan and Damian Green will continue in Whitehall, chaired by Brexit Secretary Stephen Barclay.The first meeting on Monday was title: people-believe-they-cannot-stave-off-dementia-research
story: Only one in three adults in the UK believes it is possible to reduce their risk of developing dementia, research suggests.The poll, forAlzheimerrsquos Research UK, found a lack of awareness around lestyle factors that can increase the risk of the disease and steps that can be taken to cut this risk.Almost halfof people surveyed did not know a single risk factor for dementia.These risk factors are heavy drinking, genetics, smoking, high blood pressure, depression and diabetes, while exercise is known to help protect against the disease.The Dementia Attitudes Monitor interviewed , people and was carried out by Ipsos MORI for Alzheimerrsquos Research UK.It found that just % of UK adults were able to name all the seven known risk or protective factors for dementia.This is despite experts believing that a third of all cases of dementia are influenced by factors that are under peoplersquos control, such as leading a healthy lestyle.In the poll, halfof people said they did not know dementia was a cause of death, while % incorrectly said it was an inevitable part of getting older.Mostsaid they would want to be given information in midle about their personal risk of developing dementia later in le,doctors were able to.Some % would also be willing to take a test administered by their doctor to tell them whether they were in the very early stages of dementia, even before symptoms appeared.Meanwhile, two in five peoplenamed dementia as the health condition they feared the most.More than , people in the UK are currently living with dementia and this number is set to rise to more thanone million by .Dementia is an umbrella term for a set of symptoms that affect cognitive , such as memory loss,confusion and changes to personality.Alzheimerrsquos disease is the most common cause of dementia, accounting for aroundtwo thirds of all cases.Hilary Evans, chief executive of Alzheimerrsquos Research UK, said:ldquoDementia is the UKrsquos biggest killer but only half of people recognise it even causes death, and almost half of UK adults are unable to name one of seven known risk factors for dementia including smoking, high blood pressure and heavy drinking.ldquoMany of these enduring misconceptions influence attitudes to research, with the Dementia Attitudes Monitor showing that those who believe dementia is an inevitable part of ageing are also less likely to value a formal diagnosis or to engage with research developments that could bring about le-changing preventions and treatments.ldquoMaking breakthroughs in public understanding has the potential to empower more people to take steps to maintain their own brain health, to seek a diagnosis and to support research that has the power to transform lives.Care minister Caroline Dinenage said: ldquoPrevention is becoming an increasingly vital tool in tackling dementia ndash one of the biggest health challenges of our time, and the UKrsquos biggest killer.ldquoThis research supports our Challenge on Dementia  by highlighting the need to raise public awareness around the condition and how healthy lestyle choices can reduce the personal risk of developing it.ldquoWersquove already made signicant progress on this, with advice on how to reduce dementia risk included in all health checks for the over s.ldquoBy spreading the word on prevention, we can help fulfil the Governmentrsquos ambition to make England the world leader in dementia care, research and awareness..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagaga, title: People believe they cannot stave off dementia  u research

title: leo-varadkar-to-meet-eu-leaders-to-intensify-no-deal-brexit-plans
story: Irish premier Leo Varadkar will travel to Brussels today to meet with EU leaders to intensy plans for a no-deal Brexit.The Taoiseach will meet with senior EU representatives including the President of the European Council, Donald Tusk and President of the European Commission, Jean-Claude Juncker.The leaders will discuss the detailed contingency planning under way for a no-deal Brexit.Mr Varadkar will also meet with the chair of the European Parliament steering group on Brexit, Guy Verhofstadt, commissioner Phil Hogan and the EU chief Brexit negotiator, Michel Barnier.Mr Varadkar will meet the EUrsquos chief Brexit negotiator Michel Barnier Speaking before he left Ireland, the Taoiseach said: ldquoI look forward to meeting presidents Tusk and Juncker, as well as Guy Verhofstadt, Michel Barnier and commissioner Hogan in Brussels.ldquoI will thank them for their unwavering solidarity with Ireland, and their ongoing support for the backstop as an integral part of the Withdrawal Agreement.ldquoThe Withdrawal Agreement is the best way to ensure an orderly withdrawal by the UK. We want the future relationship between the EU and the UK to be as close, comprehensive and ambitious as possible, so that the backstop will never be needed.ldquoHowever, given the ongoing uncertainty in London, we are intensying our planning for all scenarios, including a no-deal exit.ldquoMy visit is an opportunity to exchange views on the detailed contingency planning under way at both domestic and EU level, and to explore what supports might be needed..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagaga, title: Leo Varadkar to meet EU leaders to intensy no-deal Brexit plans

story: Largiesiders and cousins Stuart Currie and John McCallum secured the winners# shield, which was won by father and son pair Andrew Ronald Sr and Andrew Ronald Jr last year.Twenty pairs from theand breadth of Kintyre competed in the competition which ran from Wednesday January  to Friday January .Andrew Sr and Jr met Stuart and John in the semi-final, while husband and we team Stuart and Pat McMillan played Gavin McLachlan and his step-father Robert Todd.Gavin and Robert overcame Stuart and Pat, securing their place in the final.It was a closely fought affair for which the hall, which was lined either side with spectators, fell silent.The Largiesiders took the lead but Gavin and Robert closed the gap, making it a tense final couple of ends.Stuart and John took the shield, which is inscribed with the competition#s winners as far back as .Hall treasurer Kate McKinlay presented the prizes and thanked everyone involved, including Stuart who helped organise the competition, and the hall committee members who provided and served tea each night.
